item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Leading from the Center

The Kansas 3rd District deserves better than Kevin Yoder and the big-money interests that run the GOP agenda. Democrat Mike McCamon is a leader who knows the New Economy, has built and launched successful businesses, and has the political courage both to compromise and to stand up to Trump.

Mike is connected to our values and committed to a campaign built on transparency, small donations, and a community of Kansans who care about our future.

You and your family deserve:

  • transparency and integrity in public service
  • accessible, effective healthcare
  • education and job training for the New Economy
  • a system that rewards work, not just wealth
  • an open and safe Internet
  • common-sense regulation that most Americans agree on
  • a representative who works for you, not lobbyists

[wpforms id="172"]

item.title: Meet Mike
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_251" align="aligncenter" width="704"] The entire family out celebrating Susan G. Komen Day at the K.[/caption] A passionate defender of the Democratic Party, Mike McCamon is a fifth-generation Kansan whose family first came to the District in 1868 and settled in Argentine. His family then homesteaded in Marion County in 1872. Mike was born in Emporia and raised in a single-parent family by his mother following his father’s death. He grew up in a working class neighborhood in south Wichita, his mother making ends meet through a mix of public assistance, working as a nurse and getting a college degree. After graduating from KU he met his future wife Jody. For the better part of the next 30 years, Jody and Mike raised their family in Overland Park. In 2015 Jody was diagnosed with breast cancer. Her cancer is in remission, but this experience deepened Mike’s commitment to making health care accessible for all. [caption id="attachment_418" align="alignright" width="300"] Saying goodbye to our Peace Corps volunteer.[/caption] Mike’s two adult sons graduated from Blue Valley West. One is a software engineer in Kansas City and the other a Peace Corps volunteer in Rwanda. Their teenage daughter, adopted in 2001, is a special-needs student at Heritage Christian Academy in Olathe. For most of his career, Mike has worked in new technology—first with Kansas City’s very own Innovative Software, and then in marketing and executive roles with Apple, Intel, Iomega, Sprint, and KC startups Visual Components, iModules, and SpiderOak. In 2002 Mike became the inaugural executive director of the Bluetooth trade group and opened its first office here in Overland Park. Building consensus among thousands of competitors taught him how “leading from the center” can spark change. [caption id="attachment_250" align="alignright" width="300"] Visiting our daughter's birth country, Cambodia.[/caption] In 2009 Mike joined the executive team of WaterPartners, the nonprofit that became Water.org. For 5+ years he directed marketing, advocacy, and grassroots fundraising while helping a million people gain water and sanitation services. Water is a women’s issue in the developing world and Mike’s efforts helped women and their families in Kenya, Ethiopia, Bangladesh, India, and Haiti. While not a career politician, Mike has lived a public life. You can find out more about him on the web. To help you get started here are a few links:
  • Being named "Mr. Bluetooth" back in the day
  • Talking up the water crisis with Hank and John Green (the vlogbrothers)
  • A short TEDxKC talk, "Sh*t Happens to be a Global Problem"
  • Fun article about my work with Matt Damon's Toilet Strike while at Water.org
  • My personal blog @ mccamon.org
[pt_view id="dd444126rx"] Like many of his neighbors, Mike believes Kevin Yoder has abandoned the moderate values of the Kansas 3rd District and caved to the big-money interests that now fund all GOP politics. Mike’s campaign is different: efficient, transparent, and beholden only to voters. It’s harder to run without PAC money and big donors, but it’s a better way.
THE ISSUES
GET INVOLVED
DONATE

item.title: The Issues
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Mike McCamon believes we need leadership with the skill and courage to lead from the center and take a stand for everyday people. He believes our political discourse is polluted with polarizing positions and to move forward we must find a middle ground. Standing in our ideological opposing corners means we can never reconcile and prolongs harmful and unproductive partisanship. Below are my policy plans for the more urgent issues for the Kansas 3rd District. [pt_view id="dd444126rx"]

Policies to bring Kansans together

  • Everyone deserves affordable healthcare
  • Transparency and integrity from public servants
  • Common sense gun laws
  • Equal Rights Regardless of Sex
  • Campaign Finance Reform
  • Public Education: Priority for Kansas
  • Dignity and Compassion for one another
  • Caring immigration solutions
  • Reproductive Health Rights
  • Open and safe internet
  • Protect our Environment
  • Our economy should reward work, not just wealth

Everyone deserves affordable healthcare

 No matter your profession or station in life, every American deserves affordable healthcare. SInce healthcare now makes up nearly one-sixth of our economy, we must all be part of making it better for it to be successful for everyone. Mike believes there is no single one villain to blame for our current mess. Healthcare is a system and everyone can be part of the solution moving forward. That means government, insurance providers, and the healthcare industry - everyone. We need to build a new system that accounts for the gig economy and the end of corporate lifetime employment.
  • Create a single-payer Option
  • Mandate Medicare and Medicaid negotiate prices for prescription drugs
  • Require publicly funded centers have procedure and care price transparency
  • Create marketplace incentives for higher preventive care compliance
  • For many workers, decouple Health Insurance from employment
  • No denial for pre-existing conditions with equal premiums
  • Abolition of lifetime payout limits
  • Preventive services for women and Medicare recipients
  • Simplified Labeling and reporting of health coverage

Transparency and integrity from public servants

 Politics is not a profession. Too often our elected officials believe their constituents are the donors, not the electorate. Dark money, no matter its source, and the Citizens United case distorts public opinion and damages the integrity of our elections. We need to acknowledge that money in politics hurts our democracy. We deserve transparency from our elected officials. Who are our leaders meeting with today, yesterday? What legislative actions are forthcoming and how can the electorate weigh in on issues? Technology can play an important role. The fact that you can closely follow the lives of former high school friends online but can’t easily monitor laws that directly affect your life is absurd. Today the system is broken and must be fixed.
  • Legislate to upend Citizens United
  • Monthly Public Town Halls
  • Congressional Term Limits not to exceed 12 years
  • Refuse Corporate PAC funding.
  • Designate Election Day as a Federal Holiday
  • Complete fiscal and influence transparency
  • Simplify and modernize electorate engagement

Common sense gun laws

 Gun violence and mass shootings should not be the norm for a civilized nation. Certainly our Constitution protects our rights as gun owners, but we must legislate better solutions. Mike believes we can all agree that everyone has the right to protect their family and property. And even the most avid 2nd Amendment advocates, agree that we don’t want criminals and dangerous people to have guns. Our collective Congressional inaction to protect us from dangerous people with guns is unforgivable. Closing loopholes in the gun market and coordinating with federal and local law enforcement is our best way forward.
  • Modernize and Expand Background Check Processes
  • Strengthen Brady Bill extending it to Private Sales
  • Ban Bump stocks and other instruments that make guns battlefield ready
  • Repeal the Dickey Amendment and encourage CDC Research on Gun Violence.
  • Oppose Federal Carry Concealed Weapons Initiative
  • Support Weapons Restraining Order for those of immediate risk
  • Reinstate Federal Assault Weapons Ban
  • Mike for Kansas Campaign refuses donations from the Gun Lobby
  • Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense Distinction

Equal Rights Regardless of Sex

 Since our Independence, women have bravely fought for a voice in our government. For over a century, women have been fighting for Constitution equality in our country. An Equal Rights Amendment was first introduced in 1921 and again later in 1971. Both efforts failed. The time is now to address sex inequity in our country.
  • Reintroduction and ratification of an Equal Rights Amendment.
  • Require employers provide equal pay for equal work.
  • End the culture of sexual harassment.
  • Protect and defend womens' reproductive rights.
  • Designate Election Day as a Federal Holiday offering wider access to the polls for working women.
  • Extend Family and Medical Leave Act provision for 12 weeks parental leave to businesses with as few as 10 employees.

Campaign Finance Reform

 The only way to break the back of special interests and get more qualified citizens to run for public office is through campaign finance reform. Billions of dollars are spent on campaigns each year and a good measure of that is wasted on over saturating voters with things like direct mail and TV commercials. It has become an arms race, where there are no winners.
  • Legislate the repeal of Citizens United
  • Establish per election cycle spending caps for candidates
  • Impose a Luxury Tax on overspending campaigns
  • Create First Time Candidate Grants for qualified aspiring candidates
  • Require near real-time reporting of all donations and expenses
  • Pro-rated refunds to all donors from abandoned campaigns.

Make Public Education a Real Priority for Kansas

 Many of us, including our family, moved to Kansas and in particular this part of the state for great schools. It is a travesty that the Kansas Legislature has continuously under resourced education at all levels of the system. Great education is the background of our community and our best way to grow opportunity in the region.
  • Aggressively support local and District control and decision-making
  • Advocate Kansas Statehouse adequately and equitably invest in public education
  • Require federal mandates are funded for programs like special education programming
  • Oppose all efforts that divert public resources, such as vouchers, scholarships and tax credits, to private education
  • Design and implement programs for Student Debt Refinancing
  • Champion programs that reduce tuition at Community Colleges and Trade Schools

Dignity and Compassion for one another

 Let’s be real: every single one of us wants and deserves equality and the personal liberty to live the life that suits our true selves. Rather than striving to always finding the differences we have among us, we should be striving to see all those things we have in common. We want to be tolerated, and should not only accept but also protect others. Companies should eliminate discrimination, in every form and help lead reconciliation in the workplace. Our country’s diplomatic policies should reflect these same values abroad. We must work to make the world safe, energy efficient, healthy, and sustainable with a thriving global economy that helps everyone on the planet.
  • Equal protection for religion, sex, gender identity, and orientation
  • Incentives to accelerate adoption of renewable energy
  • Welcoming immigration policies and practices
  • Safeguards on environmental protection and preservation

Caring immigration solutions

 We are a country of immigrants and to deny this heritage is disrespectful to the real struggles many of our families faced to ultimately find liberty and prosperity in the United States. It is important to also agree that undocumented persons, immigrants, Visa card holders, and citizens should comply with our laws pertaining to the responsibilities and pathways to citizenship. Long time neighbors make our country better so helping them gain citizenship and be reunited with their families should be our priority; not arbitrary enforcement designed to destabilize our neighborhoods. A society can and should be measured by how it treats those most marginalized and at risk, and we owe it to our own immigrant ancestors to welcome everyone who strives for liberty.
  • Immediately reunite families held in U.S. custody at our borders
  • Immediately suspend funding for ICE and convene hearings on Reign of Terror enforcement tactics
  • Permanent and immediate amnesty for Dreamers
  • Reformed pathway to citizenship for law abiding people who may be here undocumented
  • Approve emergency funding for justice system to relieve ridiculous case load backlog
  • Improve responsiveness to international genocide, wars, and conflicts
  • Aggressively pursue, prosecute, and deport immigrants who threaten public safety
  • Differentiate between violent crimes and fraud or illegal presence
  • Strengthen border protection and emphatically oppose a Border Wall with Mexico.

Reproductive Health Rights

 Like our former Presidents, I support "Safe, Legal, and Rare" and a women's right to choose. Despite our differences, most every American can agree on two things: (1) people should have the right to make their own family planning decisions and (2) we should care for those making remarkably difficult decisions and comfort those affected by them. People have the liberty to make their own family planning decisions. We don't want the government to control every pregnancy. Likewise we don't want government to mandate we have 10 children either. We want the freedom to decide and our democracy should protect that right. Even the most "single issue" voters in our community practice family planning. Family planning decisions, especially those that are a result of an unplanned pregnancy, are likely the most difficult life decision women and a family can make. We should care and support those navigating that decision. They need our support. And the last point, we should comfort those impacted by that decision.
  • Women alone control their bodies and make their own medical decisions.
  • "Safe, legal, and rare"
  • Support those impacted by reproductive decisions
  • Celebrate birth and adoptive families.

Open and safe Internet

 Over the past two decades our economy has grown to depend on the public and open Internet. Our digital life in America today is one the great technological and social wonders of our times. We all want to be independent actors on this public service and users do not want their activities, identities, and personal stories irresponsibly monetized in the digital economy. Net Neutrality should be the law of the land and we must restrict intermediaries commercializing our online behavior. Like cigarette and liquor packaging, we should enforce simplified labeling of how services protect our privacy as well as easy to understand user agreements that default to the most private of settings for new users. Read my open letter to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about Restoring Trust in Facebook or my longer policy ideas for a Safer America Online Act
  • Default Privacy Settings of Internet Services
  • Validated online identities
  • Champion new Email standards to protect against phishing and hacking
  • More transparent data sharing, protection, and retention policies
  • Support efforts to encrypt online content
  • Require "Right to be Forgotten" features for internet services
  • Mandated timeframe to publicly report data breaches and compromises
  • Net Neutrality protects consumers
  • Simplified Labeling of Internet Services Agreements
  • Restrict ISP commercialization of usage data

Protect our Environment

 We must work to make the world safe, energy efficient, healthy, and sustainable with a thriving global economy that helps everyone on the planet. Our leaders must acknowledge and embrace science that shows human behavior is impacting our ecosystems, some in unchangeable ways. The US should chart an aggressive path to energy independence. Technological innovation is making fossil fuels obsolete, impractical, and inefficient. Nearly 30% of power generated in Kansas is wind energy. Through investment and incentives our country, and state, will become a leader in renewable energy.
  • Reaffirm US support for the Paris Climate Agreement
  • Ban new sales of gasoline and diesel non-farm vehicles by 2040
  • Nationally, double wind powered generating capacity by 2030
  • Invest and support the life saving work of the EPA
  • Demand the Kansas Legislature implement Net Metering

Our economy should reward work, not just wealth

 A healthy economy should be measured by low unemployment, rising wages for everyone, and less wealth disparity. Certainly entrepreneurs and Boards should have the autonomy to reward executive success, but they must also be held accountable for workplace safety and career growth. Our tax code must also maintain balance; where everyone wins by participating in and realizing the American Dream. The most compassionate fiscal policy for our country most likely means both greater spending discipline and more fair taxation schemes.
MEET MIKE
GET INVOLVED
DONATE

item.title: Media
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: == EMBARGOED UNTIL 5PM, FEBRUARY 8, 2018 === FORMER TECHNOLOGY AND NONPROFIT EXECUTIVE MIKE MCCAMON ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR KANSAS 3RD DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY Long time Overland Park moderate seeks to defeat Kevin Yoder in the 2018 Election Overland Park, KS, February 9, 2018. Today Mike McCamon announced his candidacy for the Kansas 3rd District Democratic Primary for the opportunity to challenge Kevin Yoder in the 2018 Election. A political newcomer, Mike built a successful career in the technology and nonprofit industries most notably as the inaugural CEO of the Bluetooth trade organization and on the executive team that launched Kansas City based Water.org. “Here in this part of Kansas, only a moderate and authentic voice can realistically challenge the Republican Party and Kevin Yoder in November” said Mike McCamon. He continued, “For the better part of the last 30 years, my wife Jody and I raised our family in Overland Park. Voters in the Kansas 3rd District value their families, our great community, and their individual liberties. They also care deeply for their neighbors and desperately want politicians who will take a stand against hate and corruption. “Many supporters and the leadership of the Kansas Democratic Party have been remarkably generous and kind to me as I explored my candidacy. I’m grateful for their wisdom and advice. I believe my progressive business and nonprofit background will bring a new engery and voice to the primary.” Mr. McCamon’s platform priorities are: (1) Everyone Deserves Affordable Healthcare, (2) Transparency and Integrity in Public Service, and (3) Growing an Economy that Rewards Work, Not Just Wealth. His platform also includes positions on Diversity, Immigration, Gun Legislation, and Open Internet initiatives. Mike’s first planned campaign event will be the Kansas 3rd Congressional District Candidate Forum hosted by Congregation Beth Torah in Overland Park on Sunday, February 11th at 2pm. Registration is highly encouraged and is online at http://bit.ly/2nKP7au. ABOUT MIKE MCCAMON Mike McCamon is a fifth generation Kansan who has raised his family in Overland Park for the better part of the last 30 years. A career technology and non-profit executive best known for being instrumental in the early success of Bluetooth and being on the executive team that launched Kansas City-based Water.org, a nonprofit that helps families around the world get safe water and sanitation. He was raised in a single parent family by his mother, is a KU graduate, husband, and father of three. His wife of 29 years Jody works at KU Edwards Campus and is a recent breast cancer survivor. His adult children graduated from Blue Valley West, one a software engineer in Kansas City and the other a Peace Corps volunteer in Rwanda. His teenage daughter attends Heritage Christian Academy in Olathe. Like his neighbors, Mike believes our current Congressional leadership lack the political courage to represent the values of the Kansas 3rd District. Mike believes we all deserve affordable health care, transparency and integrity in public service, and our economy reward work, not just wealth. ======= For press inquiries, please email mike[at]mikeforkansas.com or call us at 913.661.2910. Mike can be reached on his mobile at 913.940.2737. Media Kit below, click on an image to download full size image.

item.title: Meet & Greets
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Thank you for volunteering to host a Meet and Greet with Mike. Gatherings like these help you and your friends get to know Mike, but also help him to better learn the issues that matter to people in the 3rd District. The goals of a Meet and Greet are:
  1. Educate your friends about the Primary Process
  2. Opportunity to meet Candidate
  3. Discuss issues and policy
  4. Have fun!

What to Expect

Normally these events are scheduled for 90 minutes in an informal setting and are often scheduled to start at 7pm on a weeknight. The host has the freedom to make entertaining, drinks, and snacks as complicated or simple as they would like. We recommend whatever you choose, you select food you and your family will want to eat; there will be leftovers. Generally after 15-20 min of informal mingle time, the host ask attendees to sit and then introduce Mike. He will give a short 7-10 min talk about his background and discuss his platform. After that we have found 15-20 min works best for group Q&A. After some closing thoughts, Mike will be available for one-on-one detailed questions. We know everyone has busy schedules the goal is everyone has gone on their way after 90 minutes. During this primary season, a great goal is to have 15-20 registered Democrat voters attend the Meet & Greet. We want our Republican friends to also hear Mike's moderate agenda, but we do want to focus on his Democratic Primary on August 7th primary. We have found that hosts often need to invite 2x their expected attendance. There will likely be 1-3 volunteers from Mike's campaign team to help facilitate the discussion. We will send you reminders as your event date nears to make sure all is going well and answer any questions you might have for the event.

Roles & Responsibilities

Host. You are the social planner. Decide where in your home or neighborhood event space you'd like to host the event. Plan for light refreshments. Send out invite and manage RSVPs. Some folks are comfortable with doing this online, others prefer to do it the old fashioned way by calling folks. Totally up to you - it's your Meet & Greet! Once the event gets started, remember to relax and enjoy yourself. Candidate. Mike will arrive at least 15 min early and will be eager to meet your friends and neighbors. He will likely be dressed in business casual so there's no need to ask everyone to get all dressed up. Coordinator. As mentioned above, 1-3 volunteers from Mike's campaign team will help you facilitate the Meet & Greet. They will come with sign-sheets, campaign literature, and other information. The coordinator will help facilitate an interesting Q&A session and as the event winds down will make a fundraising ask on behalf of the campaign. Certainly, donating is not expected but we want you to know this ask will be made during the evening.

Things to Remember

  • Use whatever invite/RSVP system you like. Some folks have found Evite to be a convenient way to manage events like these.
  • When you publicize the event on Facebook (or other social media) we STRONGLY DISCOURAGE you to list your home address - just use "At our Home"
  • We will likely take a few pictures at the event, if any of your guests are uncomfortable appearing in photos, we will respect their wishes.
  • You hosting a Meet & Greet is one very valuable and tangible way to not only help Mike, but also connect voters with our democracy!
  • Bonus: If you have one, fly your Flag as way to show your pride in our Country!
Resources
  • Photo for Evites: (right mouse click to Download)
  • Sample Evite: http://evite.me/a4a7wHyYrw

item.content:encoded:

For nearly 100 years, women have been fighting for their Constitutional right for equal protection under the law. The time is now to end sexual inequality in our country. We should reintroduce and ratify the Equal Rights Amendment.

item.title: April Survey Results
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Affordable Healthcare Tops Issues
Thank you for participating in our recent survey. We want to stay connected with voters in the District and plan to (only occasionally) reach out to you for your opinions. Being agile and moving quickly to gather and report voter feedback is something we need from our government. Mike is a former technology industry executive who is committed to transparency and being responsive to the District. Please join us on Facebook, Twitter, or Instgram. We also send a weekly newsletter with a recap of the top story of the week. Your THREE most important issues are: 1. Affordable Healthcare, 19.1% 2. Gun Control, 16.8% 3. Education, 14.7% 4. Environmental Issues, 9.1% 5. Equal Rights, 8.5% 6. Jobs & the Economy, 6.9% 7. Transparency & Integrity, 6.8% 8. Campaign Finance Reform, 5.4% 9. Reproductive Rights, 4.8% 10. Immigration, 4.6% 11. Open and Safe Internet, 3.2% (Percent of respondents that included issue in Top Three)

Leadership team that launched Water.org, 16.3% 4. Lived in Overland Park most of last 30 yrs, 12.8% 5. 25yr technology executive, 11.9% 6. Family immigrated to Argentine, KS in 1868, 8.2% 7. Today on Facebook Live, Star editorial board members Colleen McCain Nelson and Dave Helling talk with Mike McCamon for Kansas, a Democratic candidate for Kansas’ 3rd Congressional District seat currently held by Rep. Kevin Yoder.

Posted by The Kansas City Star on Wednesday, May 30, 2018

The other week, the Kansas City Star editorial board members Colleen McCain Nelson and Dave Helling talked with Mike McCamon for Kansas, a Democratic candidate for Kansas’ 3rd Congressional District seat currently held by Rep. Kevin Yoder. Their wide ranging conversation touched on affordable healthcare and the need for more members in Congress who have experience in the technology sector.

item.title: Healthcare and ICE Survey Results
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Voters like the concept of Universal Healthcare
Thank you for participating in our recent survey. We want to stay connected with voters in the District and plan to (only occasionally) reach out to you for your opinions. Being agile and moving quickly to gather and report voter feedback is something we need from our government. Mike is a former technology industry executive who is committed to transparency and being responsive to the District. Please join us on Facebook, Twitter, or Instgram. We also send a weekly newsletter with a recap of the top story of the week. What is your HIGHEST Priority for Healthcare policy?
  1. Moving to a Universal Healthcare system, 47.2%
  2. Protecting patients pre-existing conditions, 18.1%
  3. Expanding coverage to more Americans, 12.0%
  4. Controlling Insurance Premiums, 11.0%
  5. Lowering prescription drug costs, 8.1%
  6. Price transparency for procedures, 2.3%
  7. Preventing lifetime caps on coverage, 1.3%
What is your LOWEST Priority for Healthcare policy?
  1. Price transparency for procedures, 46.9%
  2. Preventing lifetime caps on coverage, 18.1%
  3. Moving to a Universal Healthcare system, 15.5%
  4. Lowering prescription drug costs, 7.4%
  5. Controlling Insurance Premiums, 5.8%
  6. Expanding coverage to more Americans, 2.9%
  7. Protecting patients pre-existing conditions, 0.6%
Do you support the militarized tactics of ICE against immigrants?
  • Strongly Disagree, 78.2%
  • Mostly Disagree, 16.9%
  • Neutral, 1.6%
  • Mostly Agree, 0.3%
  • Strongly Agree, 2.9%
Do you support ICE separating parents and children?
  • Strongly Disagree, 90.2%
  • Mostly Disagree, 3.9%
  • Neutral, 1.0%
  • Mostly Agree, 1.3%
  • Strongly Agree, 2.3%
How would describe your family's immigrant experience to the U.S.?
  • I am a naturalized U.S. Citizen, 16.9%
  • 1st or 2nd generation U.S. Citizen, 5.5%
  • 3rd to 5th generation U.S. Citizen, 36.2%
  • More than five generations, 32.9%
  • I don't know, 5.9%
  • I'd rather not answer, 1.6%

item.title: Mike McCamon for U.S. Congress
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_796" align="alignright" width="125"] Meet Mike[/caption] Kansas Democrats need to elect a qualified candidate who can beat Republican Kevin Yoder. More and more voters in the 3rd District are supporting Democrat Mike McCamon and his moderate message to "Lead from the Center." Over his successful career in technology and nonprofit, Mike gets things done. He is responsible for the mainstream success of Bluetooth and has helped over one million people get safe water. Read more about Mike's background or policies. Mike can defeat Kevin Yoder in the Fall because he:
  • Moderate who can appeal to Republicans and independents in our District
  • Overcame personal adversity and prospered
  • Deep experience in ending gridlock by working with others
  • Understands the technology driving our lives
  • Global perspective on the issues
  • Long career of getting things done in both business and nonprofit
Read more: background or policies. [caption id="attachment_796" align="alignright" width="175"] Want a yard sign? [/caption] Since entering the race, Mike has been out meeting leaders and people like you in the District. His Monday's with Mike have hosted over 25 open town halls, and he has had one-on-one meetings with no less than 205 leaders from Wyandotte, Johnson, and Miami counties. Scroll through some of his meetings below #AroundTheThird. Read more: background or policies. [pt_view id="dd444126rx"]
MY PLATFORM
MEET MIKE
DONATE
#AroundTheThird: 180 Days of 205 Meetings

item.title: Mainstream Coalition Questionnaire
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Mainstream Coalition requested candidates complete the following questionnaire. As a strong advocate for transparency I wanted to share it publicly so you too can get to know me better and my position on the issues that matter to Kansans. Enjoy!
Q: Professional Work Background
A: For most of my career I have worked in the technology industry. First with Kansas City’s very own Innovative Software in 1988, and then in marketing and executive roles with Apple, Intel, Iomega, Sprint, and KC startups Visual Components, iModules, and SpiderOak. In 2002 I became the inaugural executive director of the Bluetooth trade group and was responsible for creating a business ecosystem of a $25B industry – one populated with component, system suppliers, end product manufacturers, service industries and even a few bigger players the likes of Nokia, Sony, Microsoft, Intel, Sony, Apple, IBM and Ericsson. In 2009 I joined the executive team that launched Water.org. For nearly six years I directed marketing, advocacy, and grassroots fundraising while helping a million people gain water and sanitation services. Water is a women’s issue in the developing world and my efforts helped women and their families in Kenya, Ethiopia, Bangladesh, India, and Haiti. My complete professional background is available at https://linkedin.com/in/mccamon
Q: Public Service and Community Organizations
A: Devoted six years of my career, below market value, to Water.org who helps people around the world get safe water and the dignity of a toilet. Elder at Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church in Overland Park, KS. Volunteer and ongoing donor for a variety of causes that address poverty and hunger in our community.
Q: How long have you lived in Kansas?
A: Born in Emporia. Lived in Kansas 37 years and the last 16 continuously in Overland Park.
Q:How long have you lived in your District?
A: 24 years, the last 16 continuously in Overland Park
Q:Why are you the best candidate running for this office?
A: Simple. I am the only candidate running for this office that has demonstrated real-world experience of getting things done in a highly networked and competitive environment. Many times over my career, in both tech and nonprofit, I created breakout success from complete ambiguity. And I have deep experience in the core challenges that drive our policy discussions around healthcare, education, and gun violence. Those challenges are as follows. Experience working toward solutions. Americans are tired of gridlock. Knowing when to stand your ground, and when to have the courage to work for compromise is a lost art in governing today. I have done this on the global stage. While leading Bluetooth, I regularly navigated difficult conversations with thousands of companies toward the end of achieving my goals for the organization. This experience cannot be understated. When you take that sort of opportunity you realize there is no syllabus on what you are supposed to do; it is a blank piece of paper and everyone is looking to you to deliver real results. Deep understanding of the technology that defines our times. I am one of only a handful of candidates nationwide that has the expertise to understand and lead the conversations about technology in our lives. We need people in our government that understand privacy, encryption, wireless technology, cyber warfare, blockchain, artificial intelligence, machine learning and the more benign threats like social media, online advertising, fake identity and ransomware. The Mark Zuckerberg hearings are the most clear example that we need more people in government who understand our digital world. Globalization. It is naive and dangerous to have an “America First” agenda when much of the world’s economy is interconnected. Our threats, markets, and workforces are all global. Over my career I have worked through partnerships, opportunities, and disagreements in over 20 different countries, navigating the culture and business ethics with grace. And we must remember, even the faces of the Kansas 3rd reflect this globalization with over 10% of our neighbors being foreign born.
Q:Indicate which of the following policies of the Affordable Care Act you support:
  • Requirement that insurers offer policies at no extra cost to those with pre-existing conditions
  • Required minimum set of essential benefits be covered in all policies
  • The prohibition on annual and lifetime limits on insurance policies
A: I am a strong advocate of these core principles of the ACA and I will work tirelessly to defend and expand them. I believe our destination should be Universal Healthcare, but mature experts in this field know you can’t “eat the whole cow in one bite.” Additionally I would lead public conversations and discorse with healthcare experts and the constituents of the District with the end goal of understanding and brainstorming. There is not a single villian in the healthcare debate. Finally, I would also explore how we could start disconnecting health coverage from employment. From the patient, legislative, and tax code point of view, this artifact of the post-war economy distorts the marketplace and overall makes healthcare more expensive. There are exceptions, but this would be the general goal.
Q: Do you believe that access to guns is a key component in school gun violence incidents and mass shootings? If so, what should be done about it? If not, why not?
A: Yes access to guns is a key component. People have the right to protect their family and their property, but how people acquire, accessorize, store, and dispose of guns should be regulated. The background check system is at best porous, and at its worse, a laughingstock. We should close the Gun Show loophole and design and implement a system that keeps guns away from criminals and dangerous people. We should immediately ban accessories that make weapons battlefield ready. Highly recommend, and even consider penalizing those who don’t store their guns safely under lock. And in Kansas we should allow guns to be destroyed if no longer wanted by our citizens.
Q: What would you do if President Trump fired special counsel Robert Mueller?
A: I would support the introduction of Articles of Impeachment.
Q: Has NAFTA done more to help or hurt the US economy? The Kansas economy?
A: Of course NAFTA has helped the Kansas and US economy. Consumers here benefit from a free flow of goods both into and out of the regional economy. Having stability allows businesses to better plan and take economic risks which helps grow our economy. This is possible under a stable and broad agreement like NAFTA. Finally, we should also remember that as a central transportation hub for both the shipping and online shopping industry, Kansas has uniquely benefited from NAFTA.
Q: Do you support comprehensive immigration reform that includes a path to citizenship?
A: Yes. We are a country of immigrants and to deny this heritage is disrespectful to the real struggles many of our families faced to ultimately find liberty and prosperity in the United States. It is important to also agree that undocumented persons, immigrants, Visa card holders, and citizens should comply with our laws pertaining to the responsibilities and pathways to citizenship. Long time neighbors make our country better so helping them gain citizenship and be reunited with their families should be our priority; not arbitrary enforcement designed to destabilize our neighborhoods. A society can and should be measured by how it treats those most marginalized and at risk, and we owe it to our own immigrant ancestors to welcome everyone who strives for liberty. Some additional positions include:
  • Permanent and immediate amnesty for Dreamers
  • Immediately suspend funding for ICE and convene hearings on Reign of Terror enforcement tactics
  • Reformed pathway to citizenship for law abiding people who may be here illegally
  • Improve responsiveness to international genocide, wars, and conflicts
  • Aggressively pursue, prosecute, and deport immigrants who threaten public safety
  • Differentiate between violent crimes and fraud or illegal presence
  • Strengthen border protection and emphatically oppose a Border Wall with Mexico.
Q: Do you think the Federal government should take action to reduce carbon emissions in the atmosphere?
A: We must work to make the world safe, energy efficient, healthy, and sustainable with a thriving global economy that helps everyone on the planet. Our leaders must acknowledge and embrace science that shows human behavior is impacting our ecosystems, some in unchangeable ways. The U.S. should chart an aggressive path to energy independence. Technological innovation is making fossil fuels obsolete, impractical, and inefficient. Nearly 30% of power generated in Kansas is wind energy. Through investment and incentives our country, and state, will become a leader in renewable energy. Some specific actions:
  • Reaffirm U.S. support for the Paris Climate Agreement
  • Ban new sales of gasoline and diesel non-farm vehicles by 2040
  • Nationally, double wind powered energy generating capacity by 2030
  • Invest and support the life saving work of the EPA
  • Demand the Kansas Legislature implement Net Metering
Q: Do you support updating the coverage formula in the Voting Rights Act of 1964 so that Section 5 can once again be enforced?
A: Yes. We should guarantee equal and open access to voting for every citizen over 18 years old regardless of race, lifestyle, sex, or station in society.
Q: Do you believe there are problems with campaign finance laws? If so, how would you propose to fix them?
A: Yes. The only way to break the back of special interests and get more qualified citizens to run for public office is through campaign finance reform. Billions of dollars are spent on campaigns each year and a good measure of that is wasted on over saturating voters with things like direct mail and TV commercials. It has become an arms race, where there are no winners.
  • Legislate the repeal of Citizens United
  • Encourage state parties establish per election cycle spending caps for candidates
  • Impose a Luxury Tax on overspending campaigns
  • Create First Time Candidate Grants for qualified aspiring candidates
  • Require near real-time reporting of all donations and expenses
  • Pro-rated refunds to all donors from abandoned campaigns.
Q: Do you think we should address the projected shortfalls in Social Security funding now? If so, how?
A: Yes we must protect Social Security. The financial instability in the fund is largely due to governmental negligence and lack of discipline. Social Security is not an entitlement; it is retireees’ saved earnings. As we repair these oversight issues, to help increase the financial stability of the system, I would work to legislate the end of the FICA cap on employee and employer contributions.
Q: Is the growing income disparity in the country a problem? If so, how would you address it?
A: There is growing income disparity in our DISTRICT! The wealth of Johnson County can only be compared to the opportunity in Wyandotte County. I am always suspect of simple solutions to intractable problems and this is one of those types of issues. There are a great many discussions to facilitate so we can discover, plan, implement, and celebrate how we can smooth the grade of county line road and the barriers it represents in our community. My focus would be collaboration, understanding, and income assistance not wage restrictions. Also this problem encompasses a wide variety of other services that needs to be considered like child care, public transportation, affordable housing, elderly care, infrastructure and access to new technology. To be effective we need a comprehensive plan for success.
Q: Do you support, and will you work to uphold, the rights decided by Roe v. Wade?
A: Yes
Q: How would you guarantee that a quality public education remains accessible to every American?
A: I am a product of the public school system as is most of my family. Great education is the background of our community and our best way to grow opportunity in the region. My platform supports:
  • Aggressively support local and District control and decision-making
  • Advocate that the Kansas Statehouse adequately and equitably invest in public education
  • Require federal mandates are funded for programs like special education programming
  • Oppose all efforts that divert public resources, such as vouchers, scholarships and tax credits, to private education
  • Design and implement programs for Student Debt Refinancing
  • Champion programs that reduce tuition at Community Colleges and Trade Schools
Q: What other endorsements have you received or are you seeking?
A: Not pursuing at this time.
Q: How much money have you raised to date?
A: ~$175K
Q: From what special interest groups have you sought—or will you be seeking—funding?
A: Not pursuing at this time.
Q: Is there anything else you would like us to know about you or your candidacy?
A: Running for this office has been a remarkably moving experience. I’ve been approaching this election very differently from everyone else - I’m spending time in the district, not just raising money. Since getting in the race I have met with 167 people one-on-one to listen and understand their issues and priorities for the district. I started with legislative leaders, then mayors, chiefs of police, hospitals, school districts, schools, teachers, business leaders, religious leaders, veterans, parents of special needs children, activists, nonprofit leaders, and lots of voters from both parties. It has informed my policy and reshaped how I see this job: it is not one about policy, but one of public service. It’s about making sure everyone gets a fair chance. It is urgently important we select a candidate from the primary that can win in November. Even with all my relevant and practical experience for the job, whoever gets elected must have immense resourcefulness, a command of how to use social and earned media to move public opinion, big ideas on how to engage and repair the trust of the electorate, an extremely supportive family, and the courage to do the right thing while standing up for us in the Kansas 3rd. It is my view, I am the candidate with the best chance to win in November and I’m grateful for organizations like Mainstream for supporting the values and priorities of Kansas.
Agreement with Mainstream Positions
The MainStream Coalition believes that people with different points of view can come together to forge good government that benefits all citizens. We are committed to good governance, quality public education, healthy communities, and sustainable fiscal policy. Our mission and more specific policy positions can be found at www.mainstreamcoalition.org/where_we_stand Do you agree with these commitments and positions? Agree

item.title: Mike McCamon para el Congreso de los Estados Unidos
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_796" align="alignright" width="125"] Comprar una camisa[/caption] Los demócratas de Kansas necesitan elegir a un candidato calificado que pueda vencer al republicano Kevin Yoder. Cada vez más votantes en el 3er Distrito apoyan al Demócrata Mike McCamon y su mensaje moderado de "Liderar desde el Centro". A lo largo de su exitosa carrera en tecnología y sin fines de lucro, Mike hace las cosas. Es responsable del éxito principal de Bluetooth y ha ayudado a más de un millón de personas a obtener agua segura. Leer mas Este otoño, Mike puede vencer a Kevin Yoder porque Mike:
  • Tiene larga historia de hacer las cosas
  • Entiende la tecnología que maneja nuestras vidas
  • Trabajando con los demás, terminará con el embotellamiento en el gobierno
  • Tiene perspectiva global sobre los problemas
  • Venció la adversidad personal y prosperó
[caption id="attachment_796" align="alignright" width="175"] ¿Quieres un cartel de patio? [/caption] Desde que se postuló a la candidatura, Mike se ha reunido con líderes y personas como usted en el Distrito. Sus lunes con Mike han sido anfitriones de más de 23 ayuntamientos abiertos, y ha tenido reuniones uno a uno con no menos de 184 líderes de la comunidad en los condados de Wyandotte, Johnson y Miami. Continúe visitando la página para conocer más de algunas de sus reuniones #AroundTheThird. #AroundTheThird. [pt_view id="dd444126rx"]

item.title: Conoce a Mike
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_251" align="aligncenter" width="704"] Toda la familia celebrando el Día de Susan G. Komen en el Kauffman Stadium.[/caption] Un apasionado defensor del Partido Demócrata, Mike McCamon es un Kanseño de quinta generación cuya familia llegó por primera vez al Distrito en 1868 y se estableció en el área de Argentine. Su familia luego trasladó su hogar a el condado de Marion en 1872. Mike nació en Emporia y fue criado por su madre después de la muerte de su padre. Mike creció en un vecindario de clase trabajadora en el sur de Wichita, donde su madre llegaba a fin de mes a través de una combinación de asistencia pública, trabajando como enfermera y obteniendo un título universitario. Después de graduarse de la Universidad de Kansas (KU), Mike conoció a su futura esposa Jody. Durante la mayor parte de los siguientes 30 años, Jody y Mike criaron a su familia en Overland Park. En 2015, Jody fue diagnosticada con cáncer de mama. Su cáncer está en remisión, pero esta experiencia profundizó el compromiso de Mike de hacer que la atención médica sea accesible para todos. [caption id="attachment_418" align="alignright" width="300"] Despidiéndonos de nuestro voluntario de Peace Corps.[/caption] Los dos hijos adultos de Mike se graduaron de Blue Valley West. Uno es ingeniero de software en Kansas City y el otro voluntario de Peace Corps en Ruanda. Su hija adolescente, adoptada en 2001, es una estudiante con necesidades especiales en Heritage Christian Academy en Olathe. Durante la mayor parte de su carrera, Mike trabajó en nuevas tecnologías, primero con la compañía Innovative Software de Kansas City, y luego en roles ejecutivos y de marketing con las nuevas empresas de Apple, Intel, Iomega, Sprint y KC Visual Components, iModules y SpiderOak. En 2002, Mike se convirtió en el director ejecutivo inaugural del grupo comercial Bluetooth y abrió su primera oficina aquí en Overland Park. El consenso entre miles de competidores le enseñó cómo "liderar desde el centro" puede generar cambios. [caption id="attachment_250" align="alignright" width="300"] Visitando el país de nacimiento de nuestra hija, Camboya.[/caption] En 2009, Mike se unió al equipo ejecutivo de WaterPartners, la organización sin fines de lucro que se convirtió en Water.org. Durante más de 5 años dirigió el marketing, la promoción y la recaudación de fondos de base mientras ayudaba a un millón de personas a obtener servicios de agua y saneamiento. El agua es un problema que afecta a las mujeres en el mundo en desarrollo y los esfuerzos de Mike ayudaron a las mujeres y sus familias en Kenia, Etiopía, Bangladesh, India y Haití.  Aunque el no es un político de carrera, Mike ha vivido una vida pública. Puede obtener más información sobre él en la web. Aquí hay algunos enlaces:
  • Siendo nombrado "Sr. Bluetooth" en esos tiempos
  • Hablando de la crisis del agua con Hank y John Green (los vlogbrothers)
  • Una charla corta de TEDxKC, "Sh * t pasa a ser un problema global"
  • Artículo divertido sobre mi trabajo con Matt Damon en Water.org
  • Mi blog personal @ mccamon.org
[pt_view id="dd444126rx"] Al igual que muchos de sus vecinos, Mike cree que Kevin Yoder ha abandonado los valores moderados del 3er. Distrito de Kansas y ha cedido a los grandes intereses que ahora financian todas las políticas republicanas. La campaña de Mike es diferente: eficiente, transparente y comprometida únicamente a los votantes. Es más difícil funcionar sin dinero PAC y grandes donantes, pero es la mejor manera.
Cuestiones CUESTIONES
INVOLECRARSE
DONAR

item.title: Cuestiones
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Mike McCamon cree que necesitamos liderazgo con la habilidad y valentía para liderar desde el centro y tomar una posición para la gente común. Él cree que nuestro discurso político está contaminado con posiciones polarizadas y para avanzar tenemos que encontrar un término medio. Pararse en nuestras esquinas opuestas ideológicas significa que nunca podremos reconciliar y prolongar el partidismo dañino e improductivo. A continuación, se encuentran mis planes de política para los problemas más urgentes para el 3er Distrito de Kansas. [pt_view id="dd444126rx"]

Politicas para unir a los Kanseños

  • Todo el mundo merece atención médica asequible
  • Soluciones de inmigración compasivas y justas
  • Transparencia e integridad de los servidores públicos
  • Leyes razonables de armas
  • Igualdad de derechos sin importar el sexo
  • Reforma financiera de campañas políticas
  • Educación pública: prioridad para Kansas
  • Dignidad y compasión el uno por el otro
  • Derechos de salud reproductiva
  • Internet abierto y seguro
  • Protección a nuestro medio ambiente
  • Nuestra economía debería recompensar el trabajo, no solo la riqueza

Todo el mundo merece atención médica asequible

 No importa su profesión o su situación en la vida, cada estadounidense merece atención médica asequible. Ya que la atención médica ahora representa casi una sexta parte de nuestra economía, todos debemos ser parte de mejorarla para que sea exitosa para todos. Mike cree que no hay un solo villano culpable de nuestro lío actual. El cuidado de la salud es un sistema y todos pueden ser parte de la solución en el futuro: eso significa el gobierno, los proveedores de seguros y la industria de la salud – todos. Necesitamos construir un nuevo sistema que tenga en cuenta la economía y el final del empleo corporativo de por vida.
  • Crear una opción de pagador único
  • Mandato Medicare y Medicaid negocian los precios de los medicamentos recetados
  • Exigir que los centros financiados con fondos públicos tengan transparencia en los precios de procedimientos y cuidados
  • Crear incentivos en el mercado para un mayor cumplimiento de la atención preventiva
  • Para muchos trabajadores, desacoplar el seguro de salud del empleo
  • Sin denegación de condiciones preexistentes con primas iguales
  • Abolición de los límites de pago de por vida
  • Servicios preventivos para mujeres y beneficiarios de Medicare
  • Etiquetado simplificado e informes de cobertura de salud

Transparencia e integridad de los servidores públicos

 La política no es una profesión. Frecuentemente, nuestros funcionarios electos creen que sus electores son los donantes, no el electorado. Dinero oscuro, sin importar su origen, y el caso Citizens United distorsiona la opinión pública y daña la integridad de nuestras elecciones. Necesitamos reconocer que el dinero en la política lastima nuestra democracia. Merecemos transparencia de nuestros funcionarios electos. ¿Con quién se reúnen nuestros líderes hoy o ayer? ¿Qué medidas legislativas están por venir y cómo puede el electorado influir en los problemas? La tecnología puede jugar un papel importante. El hecho de que usted pueda seguir de cerca las vidas de antiguos amigos de la escuela secundaria en el internet, pero no poder controlar fácilmente las leyes que afectan directamente a su vida es absurdo. Hoy el sistema está roto y debe ser reparado.
  • Legislación para hacer caer a Citizens United
  • Ayuntamientos públicos mensuales
  • Límites de mandato del Congreso que no excedan los 12 años
  • Designar el día de las elecciones como feriado federal
  • Completa transparencia fiscal
  • Simplificar y modernizar el compromiso del electorado

Leyes de armas de sentido común

 La violencia armada y los tiroteos masivos no deberían ser la norma para una nación civilizada. Ciertamente, nuestra Constitución protege nuestros derechos como propietarios de armas, pero debemos legislar mejores soluciones. Mike cree que todos podemos estar de acuerdo en que todos tienen derecho a proteger a sus familias y propiedades. E incluso los defensores de la 2da Enmienda más ávidos, aceptan que no queremos que los delincuentes y las personas peligrosas tengan armas. Nuestra inacción colectiva del Congreso para protegernos de personas peligrosas con armas de fuego es imperdonable. Cerrar las escapatorias en el mercado de armas y coordinar con las autoridades federales y locales es nuestra mejor forma de avanzar.
  • Modernizar y ampliar los procesos de verificación de antecedentes
  • Fortalecer Brady Bill extendiéndolo a Ventas Privadas
  • Las existencias de Ban Bump y otros instrumentos que hacen que las armas estén listas para el campo de batalla
  • Derogar la Enmienda Dickey y alentar investigación del CDC en violencia de armas
  • Oponerse a la Iniciativa de Armas Ocultas de Federal Carry
  • Apoyar la restricción de armas para aquellos de riesgo inmediato
  • Restablecer la prohibición federal de armas de asalto
  • Mike for Kansas Campaign rechaza donaciones del Lobby de armas

Igualdad de derechos sin importar el sexo

  Desde nuestra Independencia, las mujeres han luchado valientemente por una voz en nuestro gobierno. Durante más de un siglo, las mujeres han estado luchando por la igualdad de la Constitución en nuestro país. Una Enmienda de Igualdad de Derechos se introdujo por primera vez en 1921 y nuevamente más tarde en 1971. Ambos esfuerzos fracasaron. Ahora es el momento de abordar la inequidad sexual en nuestro país.
  • Reintroducción y ratificación de una Enmienda de Igualdad de Derechos.
  • Exigir que los empleadores proporcionen el mismo salario por el mismo trabajo.
  • Ponerle un fin a la cultura del acoso sexual.
  • Proteger y defender los derechos reproductivos de las mujeres.
  • Designe el Día de la elección como feriado federal ofreciendo un acceso más amplio a las urnas para las mujeres trabajadoras.
  • Extender la provisión de la Ley de Ausencia Familiar y Médica por 12 semanas de licencia parental a empresas con tan solo 10 empleados.

Reforma financiera de campañas políticas

 La única manera de romper con los intereses especiales y lograr que los ciudadanos más calificados se postulen para un cargo público es a través de la reforma del financiamiento de campañas. Miles de millones de dólares se gastan en campañas cada año y una buena medida de eso se desperdicia en saturar a los votantes con cosas como el correo directo y los comerciales de televisión. Se ha convertido en una carrera armamentista, donde no hay ganadores.
  • Legislar la derogación de Citizens United
  • Establecer límites de gasto por ciclo electoral para candidatos
  • Imponer un impuesto de lujo a las campañas de gasto excesivo
  • Crear becas de Candidatos por primera vez para candidatos aspirantes calificados
  • Requerir reportes casi en tiempo real de todas las donaciones y gastos
  • Reembolsos prorrateados a todos los donantes de campañas abandonadas.

Hacer de la educación pública una verdadera prioridad para Kansas

  Muchos de nosotros, incluyendo mi familia, nos mudamos a Kansas y, en particular, a esta parte del estado para excelentes escuelas. Es una farsa que la Legislatura de Kansas tiene continuamente educación con recursos en todos los niveles del sistema. La excelente educación es el trasfondo de nuestra comunidad y nuestra mejor forma de aumentar las oportunidades en la región.
  • Apoyar agresivamente el control y la toma de decisiones a nivel local y de distrito
  • Advocar que la casa del estado de Kansas invierta de forma adecuada y equitativa en educación pública
  • Requerir que los mandatos federales sean financiados para programas como la programación de educación especial
  • Oponerse a todos los esfuerzos que desvían recursos públicos, como vales, becas y créditos fiscales, a la educación privada
  • Diseñar e implementar programas para la refinanciación de la deuda estudiantil
  • Apoyar programas que reduzcan la matrícula en Colegios Comunitarios y escuelas de comercio

Dignidad y compasión el uno por el otro

 Seamos realistas: cada uno de nosotros queremos y merecemos la igualdad y la libertad personal para vivir la vida que se adapte a nuestras verdaderas personalidades. En lugar de esforzarnos por encontrar siempre las diferencias que tenemos entre nosotros, deberíamos esforzarnos por ver todas esas cosas que tenemos en común. Queremos ser tolerados, y no solo debemos tolerar, sino también proteger a los demás. Las empresas deberían eliminar la discriminación, en todas sus formas, y contribuir a la reconciliación en el lugar de trabajo. Las políticas diplomáticas de nuestro país deben reflejar estos mismos valores en el exterior. Debemos trabajar para que el mundo sea seguro, energéticamente eficiente, saludable y sostenible con una economía mundial próspera que ayude a todos en el planeta.
  • Igual nivel de protección para cada religión, sexo, identidad de género y orientación sexual
  • Incentivos para acelerar la adopción de energía renovable
  • Acoger las políticas y prácticas de inmigración
  • La protección y preservación del medio ambiente

Soluciones de inmigración cuidadosas 

 Somos un país de inmigrantes y negar este legado es una falta de respeto a las luchas reales que enfrentaron muchas de nuestras familias para finalmente encontrar la libertad y la prosperidad en los Estados Unidos. Es importante también acordar que las personas indocumentadas, los inmigrantes, los titulares de tarjetas Visa y los ciudadanos deben cumplir con nuestras leyes relacionadas con las responsabilidades y los caminos hacia la ciudadanía. Los vecinos de mucho tiempo hacen que nuestro país sea mejor, así que ayudarlos a obtener la ciudadanía y reunirse con sus familias debería ser nuestra prioridad; no aplicación arbitraria diseñada para desestabilizar nuestros vecindarios. Una sociedad puede y debe medirse por la forma en que trata a los más marginados y en riesgo, y les debemos a nuestros propios antepasados ​​inmigrantes dar la bienvenida a todos los que luchan por la libertad.
  • Reunir de inmediato a las familias bajo custodia de los EE. UU. En nuestras fronteras
  • Inmediatamente suspender los fondos para ICE y convocar audiencias sobre las tácticas de cumplimiento del Reino del Terror
  • Amnistía permanente e inmediata para los Dreamers
  • Camino a la ciudadanía para la comunidad indocumentada que haya respetado a la ley
  • Mejorar la capacidad de respuesta al genocidio internacional, las guerras y los conflictos
  • Agresivamente perseguir, enjuiciar y deportar a los inmigrantes que amenazan la seguridad pública
  • Diferenciar entre crímenes violentos y fraude o presencia ilegal
  • Fortalecer la protección fronteriza y enfáticamente oponerse a un Muro Fronterizo con México

Derechos de Salud Reproductiva

 Al igual que nuestros ex presidentes, yo apoyo "Seguro, legal y justo" y el derecho de las mujeres a elegir. A pesar de nuestras diferencias, la mayoría de los estadounidenses pueden ponerse de acuerdo en dos cosas: (1) las personas deben tener el derecho de tomar sus propias decisiones de planificación familiar y (2) debemos cuidar a aquellos que tomen decisiones notablemente difíciles y reconfortar a los afectados por ellas. Las personas tienen la libertad de tomar sus propias decisiones de planificación familiar. No queremos que el gobierno controle cada embarazo. Del mismo modo, no queremos que el gobierno obligue a tener 10 hijos tampoco. Queremos la libertad de decidir y nuestra democracia debe proteger ese derecho. Incluso los votantes de "único problema" en nuestra comunidad practican la planificación familiar. Las decisiones de planificación familiar, especialmente las que son el resultado de un embarazo no planificado, son probablemente la decisión más difícil que las mujeres y su familia puedan tomar en su vida. Deberíamos importarnos y apoyar a los que naveguen esa decisión. Ellas y ellos necesitan nuestro apoyo. Y el último punto, debemos consolar a quienes hayan sido afectados por esa decisión.
  • Las mujeres solas controlan sus cuerpos y toman sus propias decisiones médicas.
  • "Seguro, legal y justo"
  • Apoyar a aquellos impactados por las decisiones reproductivas
  • Celebrar a las familias de nacimiento y adoptivas

Un internet seguro y libre

  En las últimas dos décadas, nuestra economía ha crecido para depender del público y de la internet libre. Nuestra vida digital en Estados Unidos hoy en día es una de las grandes maravillas sociales y tecnológicas de nuestro tiempo. Todos queremos ser actores independientes en este servicio público y los usuarios no quieren que sus actividades, identidades e historias personales se moneticen irresponsablemente en la economía digital. La neutralidad de la red debe ser la ley de la tierra y debemos restringir a los intermediarios que comercializan nuestro comportamiento en línea. Al igual que los envases de cigarrillos y licores, debemos hacer cumplir el etiquetado simplificado de cómo los servicios protegen nuestra privacidad, así como los acuerdos de usuario fáciles de entender que se establecen de forma predeterminada en los entornos más privados para los nuevos usuarios.
  • Neutralidad de la red protege a los consumidores
  • Configuración de privacidad predeterminada de los servicios de internet
  • Transparencia e informes de uso compartido, protección y retención de datos
  • Identidades validadas en línea
  • Etiquetado simplificado de los acuerdos de servicios de internet
  • Restringir la comercialización de ISP de datos de uso

Protección de nuestro medio ambiente

 Debemos trabajar para que el mundo sea seguro, energéticamente eficiente, saludable y sostenible con una economía mundial próspera que ayude a todos en el planeta. Nuestros líderes deben reconocer y aceptar la ciencia que muestra que el comportamiento humano está impactando nuestros ecosistemas, algunos de manera inmutable. Estados Unidos debería trazar un camino agresivo hacia la independencia energética. La innovación tecnológica está haciendo que los combustibles fósiles sean obsoletos, poco prácticos e ineficientes. Casi el 30% de la energía generada en Kansas es energía eólica. Mediante inversiones e incentivos, nuestro país y nuestro estado se convertirán en un líder en energías renovables.
  • Reafirmar el apoyo de los Estados Unidos al Acuerdo Climático de París
  • Prohibir nuevas ventas de vehículos no agrícolas a gasolina y diesel para 2040
  • Capacidad de generación de energía eólica doble a nivel nacional para 2030
  • Invertir y apoyar el trabajo de salvamento de la EPA
  • Exigir a la Legislatura de Kansas implementar la medición neta

Nuestra economía debería recompensar el trabajo, no solo la riqueza 

 Una economía saludable debe medirse por el bajo desempleo, el aumento de los salarios para todos y una menor disparidad de la riqueza. Ciertamente, los empresarios y las Juntas deben tener la autonomía para recompensar el éxito ejecutivo, pero también deben rendir cuentas por la seguridad laboral y el crecimiento profesional. Nuestro código tributario también debe mantener el equilibrio; donde todos ganan al participar y realizar el Sueño Americano. La política fiscal más compasiva para nuestro país probablemente significa una mayor disciplina en el gasto y esquemas impositivos más justos.
CONOCE A MIKE
INVOLECRARSE
DONAR

item.title: Defeat Kevin Yoder Survey
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Primary Voters see November Congressional Election as a Toss-up
Thank you for participating in our recent survey. We want to stay connected with voters in the District and plan to (only occasionally) reach out to you for your opinions. Being agile and moving quickly to gather and report voter feedback is something we need from our government. Mike is a former technology industry executive who is committed to transparency and being responsive to the District. Surprisingly Democratic Primary Voters are rating the November election with Kevin Yoder as a "Toss Up", believes our primary keys to victory include voter turnout, sharing our plan on how our country moves forward, connecting Yoder to President Trump, and nominating a Moderate Candidate. Please join us on Facebook, Twitter, or Instgram. We also send a weekly newsletter with a recap of the top story of the week. What THREE factors will it take for the Democrats to defeat Kevin Yoder in November? Percents are of total factors selected.
  1. Strong voter turnout in Johnson County, 54%
  2. Share our plan of how our country moves forward, 41%
  3. Strong voter turnout in Wyandotte County, 39%
  4. Strongly connect Kevin Yoder to President Trump, 36%
  5. Democrat nominee who is a Moderate, 36%
  6. Expose Kevin Yoder's voting record, 27%
  7. Focus on Kevin's missteps on Healthcare, 25%
  8. Democrat nominee who is a Progressive, 21%
  9. Focus on Kevin's missteps on Immigration, 18%
  10. Focus on Kevin's missteps on Gun Laws, 16%
Compared to other people at work, school or my neighbors I am:
  1. Far more liberal, 45%
  2. Slightly more liberal, 41%
  3. All about the same, 12%
  4. Slightly more conservative, 2%
  5. Far more conservative, 0%
How would you rate the chances of the Democrats to flip this district in November?
  • Mostly likely, 20%
  • Very likely, 8%
  • Toss up, 55%
  • Not likely, 15%
  • Very unlikely, 2%
Survey methodology: We contacted 8,570 people in the Kansas 3rd District who are Democrats that voted in the 2014 or 2016 primaries. 512 of those contacted requested a link to the survey and 363 completed it. This sample size of completed surveys reflects a 95% confidence level (+/-5%).

item.content:encoded:
The Democratic Party has several candidates running for the U.S. Congress August 7th Primary. Below are three quick questions. Your answers are anonymous. Thanks!

item.title: Primary Voters share their views
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Affordable Healthcare Tops Issues. Russia meddling in Top 5
Thank you for participating in our recent survey. We want to stay connected with voters in the District and plan to (only occasionally) reach out to you for your opinions. Being agile and moving quickly to gather and report voter feedback is something we need from our government. Mike is a former technology industry executive who is committed to transparency and being responsive to the District. Please join us on Facebook, Twitter, or Instgram. We also send a weekly newsletter with a recap of the top story of the week. Your THREE most important policy issues are: Percents are of total factors selected.
  1. Affordable Healthcare, 61%
  2. Gun Control, 37%
  3. Education, 33%
  4. Russia Meddling in Elections, 27%
  5. Environmental Issues, 26%
  6. Reproductive Rights, 23%
  7. Equal Rights, 23%
  8. Jobs & the Economy, 20%
  9. Transparency & Integrity, 18%
  10. Immigration, 18%
  11. Campaign Finance Reform, 16%
  12. Open & Safe Internet, 8%
What experiences do you think Mike should highlight for voters?
  1. Helped 1 Million get safe water while at Water.org, 62%
  2. Raised by his mom in a working class home, 57%
  3. Father of a multi-racial family, 43%
  4. Lived in Overland Park most of last 30 yrs, 31%
  5. Leadership team that launched Water.org, 27%
  6. 25yr technology executive, 25%
  7. Family immigrated to Argentine, KS in 1868, 22%
  8. Wife is a breast cancer survivor, 18%
  9. Made Bluetooth mainstream, 11%
Plans for the August 7th Primary
  • I plan to vote on Election Day, 59%
  • I plan to vote using Early Voting, 26%
  • I plan to vote by Mail, 8%
  • I do not plan to vote in the Primary, 5%
  • I have already voted by Mail, 2%
Survey methodology: We contacted 11,221 people in the Kansas 3rd District who are Democrats that voted in the 2014 or 2016 primaries. 759 of those contacted requested a link to the survey and 470 completed it. This sample size of completed surveys reflects a 95% confidence level (+/-5%).

item.title: Six everyday technologies that would change our Democracy
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Like many of you, I too have contacted my members of Congress with an opinion or concern about pending legislation or topics that matter to me. You know the drill: write a letter, or more common of late, make a phone call. During the first few months of this year when I called, the most likely result was a busy signal or a full voice mailbox. We deserve better. Why is it acceptable that it is easier for my teenager to like a stranger’s funny cat video on YouTube when she’s riding along with me in the car, than for us to participate in our democracy sitting in our own homes? How is it I can know my Uber/Lyft driver will arrive in two minutes, but I have no earthly idea what my Representative is doing today, this week, last month — ever? Basically our democracy has failed to creatively implement technology to engage us as constituents, voters, and advisers. Lots of nonprofits have mastered this, but right now it seems like our feedback systems for Congress are more designed to suppress and limit comment than engage us in the democracy. Maybe it’s by design.
We don’t need a wall in America, we already have one around our government. Technology can tear down the wall between the government and the governed.
So here are six, very low tech, technologies I’d love to see on my Representative’s website. Ya’ listening Mr. Yoder? Online Calendars. What is my representative doing this week? Who are they meeting with, what legislation are they working, are there committee meetings to attend, and what’s coming up for votes on the floor? Most of what we get today is backward looking fluff. I’m sure you keep your calendar electronically so it’s really only a permissions and publishing setting. What I’m imagining is something that gives me a real-time view into what’s coming next. Shared Notes. And when you get done with those meetings, it would be great if you posted notes online for everyone to review. I know this is frighteningly transparent, but you do work for me. So just like when I send a staffer to a meeting I expect to see notes, same goes for you. Biweekly Vlogs. No less than twice a week I’d like to see a short video or podcast (think less than two minutes) on something coming up in Congress. It would be a great way to explain complex issues and a way to share insight as to why my representative plans to vote in this way or another. No script, no rehearsal. Just first person, authentic and no bullshit talk on a very regular basis. Teenagers have mastered vlogging, so can you. Mark Up Legislation. UX would be hard but maybe something like Medium where my representative could post a pending bill, write comments and then open it up for responses from constituents. If you’re looking for a research project go figure out what legislation is pending this week, what’s your congressional delegations view and what gaps of knowledge would they like to find to be better informed. Let me know what you find. Constituent Polls. Suppose there’s an important (they all are) vote coming up in the House this week. Wouldn’t it be great to have a way to be notified of that pending vote and then a way I could vote through a poll online? It could be more subtle than Yes/No, but that would be good to know as well. I’m not talking about it being binding, just some quick directional feedback. Scalable POTS. Okay this isn’t really a current “everyday technology,” but the architecture behind it’s design is quite everyday for most internet apps: virtualization. Getting ready to launch a big ad campaign, toss up a few AWS instances with a load balancer to handle the load. Design systems to automatically scale during high use. A phone number is simply a POTS (plain old telephone system) endpoint and could (with the proper design), never be busy. With most of these, you’d have to implement some sort of authentication system to ensure you don’t get gamed by bots or trolled by folks out of your district, but that’s okay because with this level of access, constituents can incur a bit of inconvenience. I suppose we need to keep the phones and email but my thinking is that if I had more engaging ways to connect with my government, I wouldn’t use them as much — and I’d likely feel more engaged and fulfilled. Reflect on your own life: are you more likely to post something on Facebook for a whole bunch of your friends to see or send a long email to each one of them? The economics of journalism today means that most of the 535 members of Congress can quietly, and without much supervision, do whatever they wish far away from the visibility of their constituents. They can blockade our input with full voicemail systems or with something as easy as a busy signal. They can refuse to host town halls and not take our appointments. This is flat wrong. We don’t need a wall in America, we already have one around our government. We deserve better.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mike, those all make so much sense! and so simple,to do --you are right, why haven't any been done??

These are terrific ideas for more transparent communication between legislators and constituents! The online calendar and notes would help by THOUSANDS of percentage points. I agree that the selected backward-looking fluff Rep. Yoder provides are more maddening than helpful. When calling, I've never been able to get an answer about how he plans to vote on a bill, even one that's due for voting that day. The attitude that a Representative works for constituents seems to be long gone.
