item.title: Public Campaign Announcement
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: FORMER TECHNOLOGY AND NONPROFIT EXECUTIVE MIKE MCCAMON ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR KANSAS 3RD DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY Long time Overland Park moderate seeks to defeat Kevin Yoder in the 2018 Election Overland Park, KS, February 9, 2018. Today Mike McCamon announced his candidacy for the Kansas 3rd District Democratic Primary for the opportunity to challenge Kevin Yoder in the 2018 Election. A political newcomer, Mike built a successful career in the technology and nonprofit industries most notably as the inaugural CEO of the Bluetooth trade organization and on the executive team that launched Kansas City based Water.org. “Here in this part of Kansas, only a moderate and authentic voice can realistically challenge the Republican Party and Kevin Yoder in November” said Mike McCamon. He continued, “For the better part of the last 30 years, my wife Jody and I raised our family in Overland Park. Voters in the Kansas 3rd District value their families, our great community, and their individual liberties. They also care deeply for their neighbors and desperately want politicians who will take a stand against hate and corruption. “Many supporters and the leadership of the Kansas Democratic Party have been remarkably generous and kind to me as I explored my candidacy. I’m grateful for their wisdom and advice. I believe my progressive business and nonprofit background will bring a new engery and voice to the primary.” Mr. McCamon’s platform priorities are: (1) Everyone Deserves Affordable Healthcare, (2) Transparency and Integrity in Public Service, and (3) Growing an Economy that Rewards Work, Not Just Wealth. His platform also includes positions on Diversity, Immigration, Gun Legislation, and Open Internet initiatives. Mike’s first planned campaign event will be the Kansas 3rd Congressional District Candidate Forum hosted by Congregation Beth Torah in Overland Park on Sunday, February 11th at 2pm. Registration is highly encouraged and is online at http://bit.ly/2nKP7au. ABOUT MIKE MCCAMON Mike McCamon is a fifth generation Kansan who has raised his family in Overland Park for the better part of the last 30 years. A career technology and non-profit executive best known for being instrumental in the early success of Bluetooth and being on the executive team that launched Kansas City-based Water.org, a nonprofit that helps families around the world get safe water and sanitation. He was raised in a single parent family by his mother, is a KU graduate, husband, and father of three. His wife of 29 years Jody works at KU Edwards Campus and is a recent breast cancer survivor. His adult children graduated from Blue Valley West, one a software engineer in Kansas City and the other a Peace Corps volunteer in Rwanda. His teenage daughter attends Heritage Christian Academy in Olathe. Like his neighbors, Mike believes our current Congressional leadership lack the political courage to represent the values of the Kansas 3rd District. Mike believes we all deserve affordable health care, transparency and integrity in public service, and our economy reward work, not just wealth. ======= For press inquiries, please email mike[at]mikeforkansas.com or call us at 913.661.2910. Mike can be reached on his mobile at 913.940.2737.

item.title: Ratify the Equal Rights Amendment
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: We need to fight the corruption and hate of the Republican party and Kevin Yoder by tirelessly working to protect fairness for everyone in our country. As a candidate the for US House, Kansas 3rd District, I call for the immediate reintroduction and ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment and I pledge to be a leading advocate for it’s confirmation by state legislatures. The Equal Rights Amendment was first passed by Congress in 1972 and simply set forth that, “Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.” Over the next seven years, 31 of the necessary 38 states ratified the amendment including Kansas in 1972. March 22, 1979 was the Congressional deadline for ratification and the amendment was never added to the US Constitution. Initially proposed by feminist and women’s rights activist Alice Paul in 1923 at the 75th anniversary of the Seneca Falls Convention, Ms. Paul believed the recently approved Nineteenth Amendment, providing women the right to vote, would not be sufficient to ensure fair treatment under the law for women and men. The time is now to protect equal rights for everyone in our country. Let’s not wait another 40 years to ensure and protect equality for women in our communities, our workplaces, our schools, and our nation. Read more? Equal Rights Amendment and Nineteenth Amendment

item.title: "Women Now" Platform
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all people are created equal, and the time is now to do something about it. Since our Independence, women have bravely fought for a voice in our government. Today February 15th, we celebrate Susan B. Anthony's birthday, a tireless advocate for women's suffrage. We need to continue the fight against the corruption and hate of the Republican party and Kevin Yoder by tirelessly working to protect fairness for everyone in our country. The time is now to address sex inequity in our country. As a candidate for the US House, Kansas 3rd District, I pledge to rigorously support a “Women Now” platform that will include:
  • Reintroduction and ratification of an Equal Rights Amendment.
  • Require employers provide equal pay for equal work.
  • End the culture of sexual harassment.
  • Protection of women reproductive rights.
  • Designate Election Day as a Federal Holiday offering wider access to the polls for working women.
  • Extend Family and Medical Leave Act provision for 12 weeks parental leave to businesses with as few as 10 employees.

item.title: Common Sense Gun Laws Now
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
I'm Mike McCamon and I'm running for the Kansas 3rd District, and we need better gun laws. Since the beginning of the year there have been 18 incidents involving guns on school campuses.
When are we going to say, "Enough is enough?"
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/mX6hGhJGITQ" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>
There are two thing about the gun issue that I know we can all agree on. People have the right to protect their family and property and none of us want criminals or dangerous people to have guns.
Here are four things we can do right now to make our country safer. We should reinstall the Federal Assault Weapons Ban. Next we need to modernize, strengthen and expand the Federal Background Check System. We should oppose all efforts to expand the Federal Conceal Carry Initiative, and we should demand our elected officials refuse to take money from the gun lobby. We just need to close a lot of loopholes in the system.
Parents and their children should not be afraid to go to school. We should do everything we can to reduce gun violence in our country.
I'm Mike McCamon and remember to vote on August 7th.

item.title: Integrity in Public Service
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
I’m Mike McCamon and I’m running for the Kansas 3rd District, and we need more integrity in our public servants.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZeZjG_okE3U" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Over the past week there’s been an enormous groundswell of disdain for politicians who gladly take money from the gun lobby - most notably the NRA. Of course I’m repulsed by it as well and have already pledged to not take their blood stained money.
Lack of progress on issues like Guns and immigration and affordable health care, and campaign finance reform and going lightly on Wall Street insiders … all boil down to the same thing - money. I recently joked that the Republican Party including Kevin Yoder actually DO serve their constituents - the problem is their constituents are special interest donors not the electorate.
I know most of you watched CNNs Town Hall meeting on gun violence earlier this week. It filled me with both hope and despair. When it comes to the biggest challenges facing our Country and our government’s lack of progress it all boiled down to student Cameron Kasky’s question to Senator Mark Rubio, “Will you continue to accept money from the NRA?” After dodged it, he couldn’t say yes. In fact he sorta defended why he’s taking the money in the first place. That wasn’t the question.
What we want from our public servants is the same genuine, authentic impatience we saw in Cameron’s face to fix Washington. Why not Mr. Senator? Why not? I think I know why.
I’m Mike McCamon and remember to vote on August 7th.

item.title: Equal Rights Now
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
For nearly 100 years, women have been fighting for their Constitutional right for equal protection under the law. The time is now to end sexual inequality in our country. We should reintroduce and ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. As a candidate for the US House, Kansas 3rd District, I pledge to rigorously support an "Equal Rights Now" platform that will include:
  • Reintroduction and ratification of an Equal Rights Amendment.

Please note Captions for the hearing impaired are available for this video on my Facebook Page. Just search for "Mike for Kansas" and check out the videos there.

item.title: We Deserve Affordable Healthcare
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/HUSsVZS_P6E" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Hi, I'm Jody McCamon my husband Mike is running for Kansas 3rd District. We need to solve the healthcare problem for everyone. I am a breast cancer survivor. In August of 2015 I was diagnosed with breast cancer. I finish treatment in September 2016 and then finished reconstruction just last month.
Because I had health insurance through my job I had a voice in my treatment plan. Insurance premiums and medical deductibles have skyrocketed over the last two years. I know. The last thing a cancer patient needs is the stress of worrying about medical bills, working through treatment, and lifetime caps. Hundreds of thousands of Americans file for bankruptcy every year due to medical bills.
We need to solve this problem for everyone. We need leaders that understand how it feels to hear the words "cancer" or "heart disease" or any other debilitating diagnosis. We need leaders who work for us, not for special interests. Mike cares about us in the 3rd District and he will work to solve our healthcare problems. Vote for Mike on August 7th

item.title: Reaching Out to Others
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Last week I reached out to the Archdiocese of Kansas City Kansas and had a lovely conversation with the Director of Pro Life. I reached out to them because my life experiences have taught me that the only path to reconciliation is to talk to people find out where we agree and not where we don't. They were patient with me, and I was with them but we didn't change each other's mind. Just for the record: I am Pro-Choice. We agree that people should thoughtfully plan their families, care for women and children, and support those that are most vulnerable in our communities. As I was leaving it occurred to me that her faith and the Democratic Party have so much in common. So instead of focusing always on this one Issue where we always disagree, not focus on where we do. We both want: <>ul>
  • "Promote the general welfare"
  • Address poverty
  • Fair Housing
  • Affordable Healthcare
  • Gun violence
  • Compassionate Immigration Solutins
  • Strengthen equal rights for everyone And that's how I'm going to end the gridlock in DC. By passionately defending our Party's platform while "Leading from the Center." Finding ways for all of us to work together on our country's greatest challenges.

item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
At times the future can look pretty scary.
I know what it’s like to be afraid. When I was a kid my dad died of cancer. I could see the fear in my mom’s eyes. “How will I make ends meet? Will my kids have a fair chance and maybe go to college?”
Today things DO look pretty scary. Our headlines are crowded with the antics of a dangerous President and a detached Kevin Yoder. Rampant gun violence. A militarized Homeland Security Department that is terrorizing our immigrant communities. Increasing costs for education and an uncertain health care market.
And there are new and growing threats like online fraud, stolen identity, and Russian meddling in our own elections. You think office automation and offshoring are scary, just wait for Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence.
Make no mistake, if we succumb to our fears, we only enable the next Donald Trump. We need to take back our country - and our democracy.
The greatness of America has never been a given; it has always been a choice. The last thing we need in Washington, DC are more lawyers.
We need people in Congress that understand how technology is affecting our lives TODAY and how it will shape our future.
In this race I’m the only candidate that can protect us online and the only one on this that can win in November.

item.title: Opinion: Mainstream Coalition
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: Late last week we learned that our campaign was not endorsed by the Mainstream Coalition. On my call with their President I thanked her and she seemed a bit surprised. I told her I have found that the times in my life where I grew the most, was when I found out I had to overcome another obstacle. In the whole scheme of things, this is just one set back. But I do think a Mainstream Coalition endorsement is valuable to capture low information voters who might wait until the last minute to do their research. The reaction online wasn't as calm and measured. The Congressional 3rd Race wasn't the only endorsement that faced a wave of controversy. The selection of Tom Cox, the Kansas House Representative that reportedly cast the deciding vote this past session to allow adoption agencies to discriminate against LGTBQ+ families, enraged many and for good reason. As for my race, several folks online questioned how deeply interconnected the support for the endorsed candidate and the leadership of Mainstream. (Yes there are many donors and public endorsements of Tom Niermann by their leadership). I have been reassured that those people sequestered themselves from the final decision, but for those voting, a colleagues' previous public support for anyone is difficult to objectively forget. Honestly, I am most disappointed in how Tom Niermann has reacted to the news and its resulting controversy. Like so many politicians these days he did nothing. Is Tom just a Kevin Yoder in a different suit? Leaders know the pulse of the electorate. When leaders do not acknowledge voter feedback we question whether or not they care. As a leader, you shouldn't feel obligated to respond to everything, you should carefully monitor the public mood. And after the Mainstream announcement, it was hard to miss online how enraged many people were about the decision. By choosing to not visit the "public square" we are left to assume Tom either isn't monitoring the pulse or doesn't care. Sounds a lot like Kevin Yoder. Leaders have the courage to be transparent. When leaders get questioned, the best path is transparency. Leaders seek to calm the waters. Leaders advocate for change.

item.title: Open Letter to Mark Zuckerberg
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: 26 July 2018 Mike McCamon Democratic Candidate for U.S. Congress Kansas 3rd District Overland Park, Kansas Mark Zuckerberg Facebook, Inc. 1 Hacker Way Menlo Park, California 94025 Mark, While we’ve never met, we know each other. Nearly ten years ago I attended the Facebook Platform Launch at NOLA in Palo Alto. Two years later I was on the executive team that launched Water.org and was brainstorming with your sister Randi at Facebook’s California Avenue HQ about how nonprofits could use your platform to advocate for grand social change. Now I’m running for U.S. Congress and I think we can help one another. Today was a bad day for Facebook. In fact one of several you’ve had lately. In my view the challenge for you and your team is about restoring trust in the conversations on Facebook. As a technologist, marketing professional, former nonprofit executive, and now candidate I would like to suggest four new features that would help you regain the trust of voters while also helping to protect the 2018 and future elections from attacks abroad executed on your platform. Implement Authenticated Identity. API abuse wasn’t at the core of the Cambridge Analytica attack, identity is the issue. Current Facebook onboarding allows new users to create identities without validation. As you know, all of the demographic data for a users’ profile is self-reported therefore making it trivial for any new user from anywhere in the world to masquerade as a neighbor. This would not be a small task, but it would be the foundational feature to protect our conversations. Overtly Sabotage Unauthenticated Users’ Profile Icons. Create a generic profile icon that is used until a user is validated and make it impossible for unauthenticated users to change their profile. The icon should overtly convey mistrust. Users are familiar with this treatment for SSL and browsers that prevent users from visiting sites that are not secure. Tune Discovery Algorithm. Once authenticated identity is implemented, tune the feed discovery algorithm to prioritize authenticated accounts and demote content and interactions from unauthenticated accounts. This way potentially fake accounts will not impact users’ news feeds. Location Aware Commenting. When users comment or interact with content on a Candidate Page, Facebook would add decoration to users who do not live in the candidate’s district. Today all users, from anywhere, can shape a conversation and/or create perceived momentum or lack thereof, and those users may be able to vote for that candidate. Facebook connects the world’s conversations. I believe in the value of Facebook and other social networks as a positive force for change in our world. I have seen it personally. But I have also seen what can happen when we let our defenses down. When things go awry on Facebook, people get hurt, relationships get broken, and elections are compromised. As a fellow technologist and American, I urge you to consider these suggestions in time to protect the 2018 Election Cycle. Your supporter, Mike McCamon mike@mikeforkansas.com Cc: Sheryl Sandberg

item.title: Final Thoughts on the Kansas Primary
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_992" align="aligncenter" width="560"] Jody and I voting on Primary Election Day 2018[/caption] It’s been a few days and Jody, the family, and I are good. Certainly it is hard to put your heart and soul into something and it to not work out as planned. We close this chapter knowing we’re blessed and surrounded by so many good people and neighbors. Thank all of you who supported our campaign, canvassed, called, texted, and followed our journeys and videos #AroundTheThird on social. You have restored our faith in the good people in this district and the possibilities in front of us. From the beginning, like throughout my career, I pledged to do it differently. In the final analysis we did prove you can make a big difference without a pile of money. Along with so many other important issues, Campaign Finance Reform will remain one of my passions. Stay tuned. There are several nonprofit ideas we are contemplating focused on our district. Let’s all stay involved in supporting our candidate for the general election. #BlueWave #OverYoder
#AroundTheThird: 180 Days of 205 Meetings
[instagram-feed]

item.title: Final Survey Results
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
The results from the survey will be posted here on or before August 20th. Please bookmark or save this page location. We will also announce results on social as well.
Who did you vote for in the Primary?
  1. Sharice Davids, 41%
  2. Brent Welder, 21%
  3. Mike McCamon, 16%
  4. Tom Niermann, 12%
  5. I'd rather not say, 5%
  6. I didn't vote, 4%
  7. Jay Sidie, 1%
  8. Sylvia Williams, 1%
At what point did you finally decide who would get your vote?
  • Day of the Election, 15%
  • In the final days before the Election, 27%
  • In the final week before the Election, 19%
  • In the final month before the Election, 24%
  • Long before the Election, 15%
What factors played the biggest role in how you got to know the candidate who got your vote?
  1. Platform & Policies, 53%
  2. Read a candidate's website, 41%
  3. Personal search online, 40%
  4. News Articles, 22%
  5. Recommendation from a friend, 19%
  6. Social Media Posts, 17%
  7. Interaction with candidate, 16%
  8. Interaction with a candidate's campaign staff, 14%
  9. Television Ads, 14%
  10. Candidate Forums, 13%
  11. Endorsements from Local Officials, 12%
  12. Meet & Greet Event, 10%
  13. Text Messages Received, 8%
  14. Direct Mail, 6%
  15. Radio Ads, 1%
How satisfied are you with the results of the Primary?
  • Very Satisfied, 36%
  • Mostly Satisfied, 35%
  • Neutral, 19%
  • Mostly Dissatisfied, 6%
  • Very Dissatisfied, 4%
How likely do you think Sharice Davids will defeat Kevin Yoder?
  • Very Likely, 16%
  • Most Likely, 19%
  • Toss-Up, 45%
  • Unlikely, 16%
  • Very Unlikely, 5%
How did you feel about getting text messages from our campaign?
  • Very satisfied, 19%
  • Mostly satisfied, 24%
  • Indifferent, 39%
  • Mostly dissatisfied, 9%
  • Dissatisfied, 9%
Survey methodology: We contacted 57,033 people in the Kansas 3rd District who were among three groups: Democrats who voted in the 2014 or 2016 primaries, Democratic non-primary voters, and also a small number of Unaffiliated Democratic/leaning voters. 1,344 of those contacted completed the survey. This sample size of completed surveys reflects a 95% confidence level (+/-3%).

item.title: The Internet: Unsafe at Any Speed
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
Facebook. I’m sure by now you’ve read about how Cambridge Analytica collected then weaponized personal data from over 50 million Facebook users for the purpose to tamper with the 2016 Presidential election for the benefit of Donald Trump. We need to remember sites like Facebook, Twitter, Google, Gmail, LinkedIn, Instagram -- all of them use your data to attract advertisers -- and to make piles and piles of money. Being able to mine your newsfeed is NOT a security breach, it is a feature. So what should we do about it? We need an open and safe internet. But first I want you to know I think the best solutions are those that are voluntarily implemented by the business; but if corporations behave in ways that harm or mislead customers, regulations are necessary.
  1. Encourage the tech sector to offer paid services instead of advertising or at a minimum, design their products so the default settings for content is COMPLETELY PRIVATE
  2. Simplified labeling of user agreements that highlight these top three attributes:
    • Does the site monetize your user data for advertising or resale?
    • Does the site share your data with other sites or services?
    • Can third-party applications store data outside of the service
  3. Require opt-back-in every six months.
  4. Require the ability for complete erasure when requested by customers
  5. Require notification of users within 72 hours of any known security breach
Some would say these ideas go too far. We need someone to stand up to the tech sector the way Ralph Nader did to the automotive industry. We need seat belts for digital age. Mike McCamon and I’m running for Kansas 3rd. Follow us anywhere on social at mikeforkansas. And remember to vote on August 7th. [Please note Captions for this video are available at https://facebook.com/mikeforkansas]

item.title: Support March for Our Lives KC
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
NEVER AGAIN should we allow events like Parkland repeat themselves. Let's celebrate every student who now leads our nation to real solutions. Our community supports the principle that people should be able to protect their family and their property. And that criminals and a dangerous people should not have guns. I want us to:
  1. Modernize and expand the background check system for gun purchases
  2. Ban accessories that make weapons battlefield ready
  3. Oppose federal concealed carry initiative
  4. Support a weapons restraining order for those of immediate risk
  5. Repeal the Dickey Amendment so that the CDC can resume research on mental health and gun violence
  6. Reject members of Congress who accept money from the gun lobby
Let’s not stop here. I’m supporting our young adults and the March on the 24th! Please note Captions for this video are available at https://facebook.com/mikeforkansas

item.title: Laura, SMSD Teacher, supports Mike
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: My name is Laura and I live in Overland Park and I teach in the Shawnee Mission School District. I have known Mike McCamon for more than 20 years and I have watched Mike and Jody raise their children, weather many joys and sorrows, job changes, relocations, along with the ups and downs and sorrows of life. And two major medical crises that many families would have not made it through. Over all the years that I have known Mike, and everything I've watched him go through, I have never once seen him lose his cool. I don't think I know any person who is more even keel than Mike McCamon. Mike is not usually the first person in the room to talk, but when Mike does decide to speak, he has something valuable to say. I am always impressed by his intelligence and his common sense approach of whatever idea he has to share.In addition to the way he can come up with solutions to problems. The thing that impresses me the most about Mike is his heart. Mike Has Matthew Chapter 25 kinda values. He shows it in the way he lives his life and I’ve watched him teach those values to his children. I believe that Mike's desire to run for public office is not motivated by any desire to glorify himself, but is motivated by a real desire to serve people. You hear that a lot from people who run for office, but then it seems like mostly they’re interested in serving their own agenda. That is why Mike will earn my vote for the Kansas 3rd Congressional District Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: Nancy, adoptive mother, supports Mike
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: My name is Nancy and this is my son, Maddox, he's 14 and I'm a stay at home mom. I support Mike for Kansas because he cares about families and Equal Rights for everyone. I am Pro-Choice because I don't think other people should be allowed to tell me what I can do with my body. Every family is different, but for our family my husband and I chose international adoption. I'm excited that Mike is running for US Congress because his family appeals to a variety of families. He has a traditional family, having had two biological children. And they are also an adoptive family with a child with medical needs. I support Mike for Kansas because he is not a career politician. He has a lot of life experiences and a variety of areas that can help others think outside of the box when solving the problems that we're facing today. I support Mike for Kansas because he supports families and Equal Rights for everyone. Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: First Quarter Campaign Results
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
UPSTART MODERATE RAISES $152,425 FOR KANSAS 3RD DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY IN BID TO UNSEAT KEVIN YODER IN 2018
Mike McCamon taking unconventional path to nomination by connecting in the community and focusing less on fundraising OVERLAND PARK, KS. Today the Mike for Kansas Campaign Committee released its first Campaign Quarterly Report. The campaign raised $152,425 while only spending $6,917 leaving the upstart moderate with $145,509 cash on hand at the end of quarter. Focusing on local support, the campaign highlighted that 72% of donations were from Kansas 3rd District voters. Mike McCamon, a career technology and non-profit executive, is a strong supporter of campaign finance reform as a way to end legislative gridlock and bring more diversity to our government. The focus of the campaign has been to connect with scores of leaders in the community regardless of party. The campaign announced that in the 62 days Mike has been in the race, he has hosted no fewer than 95 one on one meetings with local leaders in state and local government, school districts, nonprofits, local businesses, healthcare, labor, higher education, chamber of commerces, police and fire safety. “Most every voter I meet tells me they believe the most corrupting force in politics is money. It was clear to me that if I wanted to change the system, I needed to take the lead myself and campaign differently,” said Mike McCamon. He continued, “Rather than spending my time on the phone asking for donations I’ve spent my days and weeks around the district, building a foundation for a campaign against Kevin Yoder in the Fall. The math is clear: the Kansas 3rd District is moderate and mostly Republican, so our party’s only path to victory is a candidate and platform that appeals to mainstream voters.” Having previously built worldwide brands like Bluetooth and Water.org, McCamon’s campaign has focused on networking and timely content to garner support from voters in the district. The campaign’s video strategy has resulted in over 34,000 unique views on topics ranging from health care, adoption, gun laws, to equal rights and online privacy. While Kevin Yoder and the rest of the Democratic field for the Kansas 3rd District remained silent this week, McCamon highlighted posts, videos, and podcasts as the nation focused on Facebook and online privacy. Mike and his wife Jody, made a sizable loan to the campaign for its operating reserve budget. Per FEC guidelines, this loan is considered funds raised for reporting purposes. The full financial reports will be available from the FEC website next week. ABOUT MIKE MCCAMON Mike McCamon is a fifth generation Kansan who has raised his family in Overland Park for the better part of the last 30 years. A career technology and non-profit executive best known for being instrumental in the early success of Bluetooth and being on the executive team that launched Kansas City-based Water.org, a nonprofit that helps families around the world get safe water and sanitation. He was raised in a working class single parent family by his mother after his father died. Mike is a KU graduate, husband, and father of three. His wife of 29 years Jody works at KU Edwards Campus and is a recent breast cancer survivor. His adult children graduated from Blue Valley West, one a software engineer in Kansas City and the other a Peace Corps volunteer in Rwanda. His teenage daughter attends high school in Olathe. Like his neighbors, Mike believes our current Congressional leadership lack the political courage to represent the values of the Kansas 3rd District. Mike believes we all deserve affordable health care, transparency and integrity in public service, safer gun laws and equal rights for everyone. ======= For press inquiries, please email mike[at]mikeforkansas.com or call us at 913.661.2910. Mike can be reached on his mobile at 913.940.2737.

item.title: We all get a seat at the table
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: I’m Lynn and I’m Gina and we been together for 30 years our family is not your typical family. We are two women and we have two children that became part of our family through adoption. Our oldest child is transgender. Yes and we got married on the thirtieth anniversary of our first date - legally married. I've never felt uncomfortable about being gay or being Jewish. Mike and Jody are very inclusive. They welcome all kinds of differences in people I think that I get the impression from both of them that it enriches their lives. I think what Mike offers for me -- is a seat at the table. He allows me the opportunity to be just exactly who I am. He's an advocate for biological families, for adoptive families. He's a wonderful advocate for all races, and all people and I think that he will do a wonderful job because he's open minded and he's willing to say "I don't understand this, teach me." When its Mike turn to lead, I fully expect him to him to have a open mind and an open heart to families who are not your average run of the mill family. It is time for us to have someone that will listen to us Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You have my vote. I love what I read. We can hope can’t we !

item.title: Money is the core issue in politics
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: Money.It's at the core of most every single problem we have in politics today. Money from the gun lobby leads to looser gun laws. Money from the healthcare and insurance lobbies means we have higher premiums, less coverage, and fewer choices. Money from the oil and gas industries, loosen laws that protect our environment. Money from Wall Street led to the Republican tax cut that rewarded the rich and will likely the cripple our economy. And the worst? Money silences our voices from being heard. As a strong advocate for campaign finance reform, I thought I should probably start with me. Focus on winning over voters in the primary, not on raising money. Make sure everyone's voice in our community is heard. Not just those of the rich or special interests. One of the many reasons why I'm running for US Congress is because I believe the only way we can solve our biggest problems is by having people act and think differently. Of course we need to legislate the end of Citizens United. Of course, we need to expose the dark money in politics. But we need to look at ourselves as well. People from around here know change starts at home first. Long before you get elected. I'm Mike McCamon and running for US Congress. I hope to get your vote on August Seventh. Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: Thoughts from Earth Day 2018
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
We must work to make the world safe, energy efficient, healthy, and sustainable with a thriving global economy that helps everyone on the planet. Our leaders must acknowledge and embrace science that shows human behavior is impacting our ecosystems, some in unchangeable ways. The US should chart an aggressive path to energy independence. Technological innovation is making fossil fuels obsolete, impractical, and inefficient. Nearly 30% of power generated in Kansas is wind energy. Through investment and incentives our country, and state, will become a leader in renewable energy.
  • Reaffirm US support for the Paris Climate Agreement
  • Ban new sales of gasoline and diesel vehicles by 2040
  • Nationally, double wind powered generating capacity by 2030
  • Invest and support the life saving work of the EPA
  • Demand the Kansas Legislature implement Net Metering
Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: 78 Days of Listening
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: Our voices are not being heard in Washington. Since getting into this race 78 days ago I have had 110 one on one, face to face meetings with leaders in our community. From elected officials, to doctors. Lawyers, educators, students, parents, immigrants. Business people, gun shop owners, pastors, school board members, chiefs of police, and everyday people just like you. I’m doing it not to share my story or my agenda. I’m doing it to listen. To listen to your challenges. Listen to your fears. To listen to your hopes and dreams. I’m asking how we can fix things because I believe we can do better. America’s greatness has never been a given. It has always been a choice. Do we extend a helping hand to those less fortunate than ourselves? Do we stand up for injustice, here and abroad? Do care for our neighbors the way we were cared for as children. And will we choose to have patience and grace for every opinion and perspective. Like so many of you, I’m not going to sit back and wait for things to get better. I’m going to roll up my sleeves and get to work. That’s all I know how to do. Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: Growing Up in a Single Parent Family
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: My father died when I was 11. Nothing up to that point distracted me from a carefree childhood. When you’re young, everyone seems is invincible. But my dad didn’t live a healthy lifestyle and cancer took his life at 40. After he died, we moved to Wichita. My mom went to school and worked a job struggling to make ends meet. We were on public assistance for a while as well. But through it all, we never focused on what we didn’t have, we worked on making tomorrow better than yesterday. Last weekend I was back on the south side of Wichita. If you don’t know that part of town, it’s a modest and simple working class neighborhood on that “side of the tracks.” We didn’t have much, but we had enough. I spent summers played down by the river and as much as I hated it, long afternoons at the downtown library. My mom saw to it, that both her kids graduated from college. I’m not just a technology and nonprofit executive who’s raised his family in Overland Park. I’m also a kid from a single parent home who learned early to keep his head high, keep going, and never ever give up. Everyone deserves a fair chance. Tomorrow doesn’t have to be the prisoner of today. And when I go to Congress, I’ll make sure everyone gets a chance at the American dream. From every walk of life, from every part of town. Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: National Teacher Appreciation Week
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
As most of you know, it’s National Teacher Appreciation week. Many of us moved to this part of the state for great schools - and their great teachers, staff, administration and leadership. Now more than ever it’s important to remember that our public schools are on the front lines if our country’s biggest challenges. Immigration. Mental health. Bullying. And of course Gun Violence. In fact school is the only safe place for some students even right here in our community. And unlike cake shops in Colorado, or now adoption agencies in Kansas; our public schools do not discriminate - they bravely educate every student that walks in the front door. Too often, their success is taken for granted. We all know great affordable education at every level is the backbone of our community and our best way to grow opportunity in the region. As a member of Congress I would
  • Aggressively support local and District control of decision-making
  • Advocate that the Kansas Statehouse adequately and equitably invest in public education
  • Require federal mandates are funded for programs like special education programming
  • Oppose every effort that diverts public resources, such as vouchers, scholarships and tax credits, to private education
  • Design and implement programs for Student Debt Refinancing
  • Champion programs that reduce tuition at Community Colleges and Trade Schools
Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: On the Greatness of American this Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: "The greatness of America is not a given, it has always been a choice." I got this quote from Pastor Tom Are at Village Presbyterian Church. I’m not sure if it’s his own take on Obama’s similar quote in the 2009 Inaugural Address or from someplace else. Regardless of the source, I have found it inspiring and want to share a bit more about it this Memorial Day weekend. For me, the idea rests in the truth that if you think something is broken or wrong you should try to fix it. Like Eldridge Cleaver's "you are either part of the solution, or part of the problem." Our collective greatness as a country has been defined by those times we righted a moral injustice. Some highlights would include the abolition of slavery, women's suffrage, ending child labor, civil rights, ending Jim Crow, ending school segregation with Brown v. Board of Education, and marriage equality. Or when we responded to international crisis like (for the first 150 years of our country) a mostly open immigration policy, World Wars, the Holocaust, the formation of the Peace Corps, and our collective response to natural disasters like tsunamis or earthquakes abroad. And it also includes our democratic experiment, landing people on the moon, our role in the fall of Eastern Europe, and the many innovations and inventions we have discovered and shared with humanity. But it also provides a window into our collective shame like our role in the slave trade, our founders’ treatment of the indigenous peoples of America, our slow response to AIDS, and our complacency toward racism here and genocide in places like Rwanda and Cambodia - and now in Myanmar. It is also shameful how our leaders refuse to respond to gun violence. We are great, when we choose to do the right thing and we are at our worse when ignore suffering or perpetuate hate on others and our world. Our current President, and too many of our elected officials, choose to not be "part of the solution" and therefore cannot lead us to future greatness. Yes, there is still much work to be done in making ours a "more perfect union." Our collective greatness is not a given. We can't just roll out of bed and it happens. We have to choose to be awake, show up, learn from the folks in the trenches what should be done, ask others to help, find money to do it (if needed), and stand our ground. And some have had to die in those fights - and there we find the real meaning of Memorial Day. As MLK said, "The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice." We as a country can help with the bending, but we have to choose.

item.title: Russia is Attacking our Democracy
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: We have become numb to the fact that Russia infiltrated our social networks and is threatening our democracy and our basic values. While we were all staring at our mobile phones, we wandered into the digital age and we are all beginning to realize, we are not safe. For nearly three decades I worked at both tech startups and titans like Apple and Intel. As technology transforms more and more of our daily lives, it is clear Congress needs new faces with the experience to protect you and your family from Russia, scammers, and hackers. We need people in Congress who deeply understand trends like online privacy, encryption, blockchain machine learning, intelligent assistants, and net neutrality. It is very dangerous that the tech sector drives much of our new economy while most of our elected leaders do not even understand how Facebook works. We need public discourse and discussions on topics like Privacy. What data can companies save about you? What are the defaults when you establish a new account? How long can your data be saved? Can your data be shared? Do you have the right “to be forgotten?” How is your data protected, and are there penalties if it isn’t? At the core, Russia’s plan was to spoof us with fake accounts, fake news, and bots that made all of it look very real. We should start be requiring places like Facebook and Twitter ensure their users are real and authenticated. Both platforms should also take a much closer look at how they approve and monitor companies like Cambridge Analytica that legally mined the personal data of millions of users without Facebook even realizing it. And yes we need to also consider the ethics of new technology. As companies deploy automation, should they be responsible for displaced workers? Do we worry about the amount of energy that’s needed to keep gigantic server farms running around the clock, all over the world? Should we revisit our protections for children? How do we deal with freedom of expression, hate, and bullying online? And what about distracted driving and how our collective digital obsessions are affecting our personal relationships and evening dinners. Judging by Mark Zuckerberg’s testimony on the Hill, I’m sure most people watching this video know more about Facebook than most members of Congress. We need people in Washington, DC that actually understand how technology is affecting our lives TODAY and how it will shape our future. We must address this threat now or we will enable the next Russia - or worse. My name is Mike McCamon and I’m running for US Congress. I am the only candidate running in this race with the technical background to protect you and your family online. I hope to get your vote on August 7th. Please note, all of our videos are available CC on Facebook

item.title: Safer America Online Act
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: How can we be protected online? A few thoughts from this weekend on a plan for a Safer America Online. The Great American Firewall. Won't work and I wouldn't support it. China has done this to block internet traffic from abroad and this won't work here in the US. This idea ignores the risk of foreign actors and devices already here but infringes on the 1st Amendment not to mention the infrastructure of the internet is a "single point of entry". Walls are lame - whether on the internet or on our southern border. Net Neutrality. And speaking of walls, every American deserves equal access to the internet. Net Neutrality protected innovators, entrepreneurs, businesses, educators, and users ability to play on a level playing field - a founding principle of the internet and it's underlying standards. Congress should take action to protect these rights online while also restricting the commercialization of user traffic. Identity Verification. Anyone can create an account on a service like Facebook and claim to be whomever they want. They don't verify where they live, their age, and their name. It's like people buying airplane tickets and arriving at the airport with no ID - and the airlines don't care. This is one of basic issues that I believe is at the core of election meddling. It's not an email compromise that moves the vote, it's fake users on places like Facebook shaping the conversation in false ways. Multi-Factor Authentication. When it comes to pedestrian email and network hacking this is our best defense. There is mounting evidence it should be a physical key and not just a text message as the latter is exposed to being compromised. Physical keys have worked for a long time to lock down our stuff and the technology exists today to use them for the web. Email Standards. Philosophically it's easy to see why most breaches start with email. Nearly every one of us has a place where anyone on the planet can send us a message with nefarious links that can link to malware or worse. We should champion efforts to rethink email in our less-trusted online world. There is a lot of ground here but it's way more than spam filters. Enact our own version of the EU General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR). Most of this is around privacy but it's worth a look. Best news is U.S.-based companies have likely already implemented it to be compliant to do business in Europe. Encryption. I am a fan of encryption and more services should implement it. If your data is encrypted, you are a less valuable target. Too many developers these days don't take encryption and data management in mind when they build web apps and leave user data exposed if their systems are compromised. IoT Audit. Most of us have 5+ devices in our home that are connected to the internet - that's in addition to our router, computers, and phones. A thermostat, a garage door opener, and even a door bell. These devices have an operating system and subcomponents that are sourced and maintained in ways that are not state of the art like servers and computers. The IoT should develop certification programs that give users more confidence in these devices' security. Age Restrictions. Current law requires a person to be 13 yrs or older to have an online account - like on SnapChat or Facebook. The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act was written nearly 20 years ago. That was long before smartphones, social networks, and pervasive photo/video sharing services. We should have a national conversation on whether or not that age should be raised to 16.

item.title: Open Letter to Facebook
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded: 26 July 2018 Mike McCamon Democratic Candidate for U.S. Congress Kansas 3rd District Overland Park, Kansas Mark Zuckerberg Facebook, Inc. 1 Hacker Way Menlo Park, California 94025 Mark, While we’ve never met, we know each other. Nearly ten years ago I attended the Facebook Platform Launch at NOLA in Palo Alto. Two years later I was on the executive team that launched Water.org and was brainstorming with your sister Randi at Facebook’s California Avenue HQ about how nonprofits could use your platform to advocate for grand social change. Now I’m running for U.S. Congress and I think we can help one another. Today was a bad day for Facebook. In fact one of several you’ve had lately. In my view the challenge for you and your team is about restoring trust in the conversations on Facebook. As a technologist, marketing professional, former nonprofit executive, and now candidate I would like to suggest four new features that would help you regain the trust of voters while also helping to protect the 2018 and future elections from attacks abroad executed on your platform. Implement Authenticated Identity. API abuse wasn’t at the core of the Cambridge Analytica attack, identity is the issue. Current Facebook onboarding allows new users to create identities without validation. As you know, all of the demographic data for a users’ profile is self-reported therefore making it trivial for any new user from anywhere in the world to masquerade as a neighbor. This would not be a small task, but it would be the foundational feature to protect our conversations. Overtly Sabotage Unauthenticated Users’ Profile Icons. Create a generic profile icon that is used until a user is validated and make it impossible for unauthenticated users to change their profile. The icon should overtly convey mistrust. Users are familiar with this treatment for SSL and browsers that prevent users from visiting sites that are not secure. Tune Discovery Algorithm. Once authenticated identity is implemented, tune the feed discovery algorithm to prioritize authenticated accounts and demote content and interactions from unauthenticated accounts. This way potentially fake accounts will not impact users’ news feeds. Location Aware Commenting. When users comment or interact with content on a Candidate Page, Facebook would add decoration to users who do not live in the candidate’s district. Today all users, from anywhere, can shape a conversation and/or create perceived momentum or lack thereof, and those users may be able to vote for that candidate. Facebook connects the world’s conversations. I believe in the value of Facebook and other social networks as a positive force for change in our world. I have seen it personally. But I have also seen what can happen when we let our defenses down. When things go awry on Facebook, people get hurt, relationships get broken, and elections are compromised. As a fellow technologist and American, I urge you to consider these suggestions in time to protect the 2018 Election Cycle. Your supporter, Mike McCamon mike@mikeforkansas.com Cc: Sheryl Sandberg

item.title: Vision & Leadership: Making Bluetooth Mainstream
item.dc:creator: MinAd1781
item.content:encoded:
<iframe width="500" height=500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Hi-q4Yjh7Lw" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Isn't that what we desperately want from DC?
Mike has real world experience bringing people together around an idea and leading teams through adversary to deliver on big goals. You have Bluetooth in your phone? Mike helped to make that happen.
Eric, who worked for Mike at the Bluetooth trade group, talks about the task and what he learned from Mike back in the early days of the technology. [Excerpt from longer Facebook LIVE found in videos tab of Mike McCamon for Kansas]
Be sure to vote on TUESDAY in the Democratic Primary for Mike McCamon for U.S. House KS-03.
